triathlon competitions are up and running in Paris on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier.\n\nMore rain came into Paris overnight but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 J"}, "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports", "wgt": 81}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Triathlon", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Triathlon", "wgt": 81}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Triathlon", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Triathlon", "wgt": 85}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 159}, "sentiment": 0.07450980392156858, "breakingScore": 0.4662894670694011}
{"uri": "8251435717", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/sports/men-s-olympic-triathlon-postponed-in-paris-over-seine-water-quality-concerns/article_83bcc896-4ec1-11ef-a1b5-53d3f4e7eb08.html", "title": "Men's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns", "body": "PARIS -- Olympics organizers are banking on the sun and scorching temperatures to improve the water quality of the Seine River enough for triathletes to swim in it.\n\nOtherwise, they could be feeling the heat.\n\nConcerns about the Paris river's cleanliness postponed the men's triathlon on Tuesday, with officials hoping the swimming portion of the race will soon be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway following an expensive cleanup effort.\n\nOrganizers said they will try to hold the men's triathlon Wednesday instead. The women's competition also is scheduled that day, but both will only happen if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is also planned as a backup date.\n\nHowever, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate rescheduling because rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider said. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim, leaving uncertainty about its accuracy the day of the race.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) to improve the water quality in the Seine so the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming event next week could be held in the famed river that runs through the city center. But bacteria levels have remained in flux.\n\nOrganizers were asked if they put the aesthetics of the triathlon over the best interests of athletes.\n\n\"We're living in the 21st century where, unfortunately, there are far more meteorological events that happen that are beyond the control of the organizers,\" Merle said. \"We've seen that we go from heavy rain to extreme heat like today in very few days. So it's actually hard to control how it can affect the quality of a river.\"\n\nParis experienced a downpour during the Olympic opening ceremony Friday, with rain persisting into Saturday. The swimming portion of training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course was canceled on both Sunday and Monday because of concerns over water quality.\n\nOrganizers had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that apparently wasn't sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety. The sun's ultraviolet rays can kill the bacteria and lower levels, and the early part of the week has been hot and sunny.\n\nThe sport's governing body, World Triathlon, its medical team, the IOC and city officials met early Tuesday and decided to postpone.\n\nRider, the triathlete, was on a 4 a.m. run when the delay was announced. A fellow triathlete also out running waved him down.\n\n\"We had a little chat there in the pitch black, at 4 a.m., in the middle of the street, no one around,\" Rider said. \"I just went back to the room and went back to bed.\"\n\nParis Deputy Mayor Pierre Rabadan said \"the trend is improving\" but did not rule out further delays \"if there is an issue tomorrow after the results of the analysis.\"\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\"\n\nBut experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk. \"There's nothing magic about 900,\" said Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida.\n\nOne of four test sites was below the threshold for E. coli on Tuesday, said Merle of Paris 2024. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the threshold.\n\nThe men's triathlon is now scheduled to start at 10:45 a.m. Wednesday, which may make heat more of a factor with the event finishing at the hottest part of the day. World Triathlon is planning to provide ice and water stations along the course for the athletes. The women's race is set to go forward at 8 a.m. as originally planned.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming after delays, that part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward. That happened last year at the European Championships when the triathlon format was switched because of water quality issues.\n\n\"It's just another situation of the competition,\" said World Triathlon president Marisol Casado, pushing back against the idea that a switch would be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water.\n\nOther swimming events planned in the Seine are the triathlon mixed relay on Monday and the women's and men's marathon swimming events on Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. Marathon swimming could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nBut it's a logistical challenge for triathlon to switch swimming locations given that routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\n\"We are sympathetic,\" Merle said. \"Let's see how it goes.\"", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "pat_graham@santamariatimes.com", "name": "Pat Graham", {"uri": "2024-07-438937595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:25:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:25:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:23:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.wlky.com/article/olympic-triathletes-will-swim-in-paris-seine-river-after-water-quality-concerns/61746010", "title": "Olympic triathletes will swim in Paris' Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.The decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.Related video above: The Men's Olympic Triathlon was postponed due to high bacteria levels in the River SeineThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.Elevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.The water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.Every day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.High levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.Daily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.Plus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.Merle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.Organizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.Efforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nRelated video above: The Men's Olympic Triathlon was postponed due to high bacteria levels in the River Seine\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. {"uri": "2024-07-438963213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:16:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:16:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/sports/olympics/olympics-triathlon-swimming-seine-river/507-28f80d86-de85-495d-b3ce-a508ee4e9ade", "title": "After days of uncertainty, Olympic triathletes will swim in Seine River", "body": "The decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city and Olympics organizers.\n\nPARIS, France -- After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.", "source": {"uri": "fox61.com", {"uri": "2024-07-438749399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:22:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:22:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:04:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/men-s-olympic-triathlon-postponed-in-paris-over-seine-water-quality-concerns/article_3f0a741b-c6b9-52b0-a7b6-ecf9d51dff5c.html", "title": "Men's Olympic triathlon postponed in Paris over Seine water quality concerns", "body": "Concerns about water quality in the Seine River led Paris Olympics organizers to postpone the men's triathlon\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Olympics organizers are banking on the sun and scorching temperatures to improve the water quality of the Seine River enough for triathletes to swim in it.\n\nOtherwise, they could be feeling the heat.\n\nConcerns about the Paris river's cleanliness postponed the men's triathlon on Tuesday, with officials hoping the swimming portion of the race will soon be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway following an expensive cleanup effort.\n\nOrganizers said they will try to hold the men's triathlon Wednesday instead. The women's competition also is scheduled that day, but both will only happen if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is also planned as a backup date.\n\nHowever, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate rescheduling because rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider said. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim, leaving uncertainty about its accuracy the day of the race.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) to improve the water quality in the Seine so the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming event next week could be held in the famed river that runs through the city center. But bacteria levels have remained in flux.\n\nOrganizers were asked if they put the aesthetics of the triathlon over the best interests of athletes.\n\n\"We're living in the 21st century where, unfortunately, there are far more meteorological events that happen that are beyond the control of the organizers,\" Merle said. \"We've seen that we go from heavy rain to extreme heat like today in very few days. So it's actually hard to control how it can affect the quality of a river.\"\n\nParis experienced a downpour during the Olympic opening ceremony Friday, with rain persisting into Saturday. The swimming portion of training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course was canceled on both Sunday and Monday because of concerns over water quality.\n\nOrganizers had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that apparently wasn't sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety. The sun's ultraviolet rays can kill the bacteria and lower levels, and the early part of the week has been hot and sunny.\n\nThe sport's governing body, World Triathlon, its medical team, the IOC and city officials met early Tuesday and decided to postpone.\n\nRider, the triathlete, was on a 4 a.m. run when the delay was announced. A fellow triathlete also out running waved him down.\n\n\"We had a little chat there in the pitch black, at 4 a.m., in the middle of the street, no one around,\" Rider said. \"I just went back to the room and went back to bed.\"\n\nParis Deputy Mayor Pierre Rabadan said \"the trend is improving\" but did not rule out further delays \"if there is an issue tomorrow after the results of the analysis.\"\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\"\n\nBut experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk. \"There's nothing magic about 900,\" said Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida.\n\nOne of four test sites was below the threshold for E. coli on Tuesday, said Merle of Paris 2024. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the threshold.\n\nThe men's triathlon is now scheduled to start at 10:45 a.m. Wednesday, which may make heat more of a factor with the event finishing at the hottest part of the day. World Triathlon is planning to provide ice and water stations along the course for the athletes. The women's race is set to go forward at 8 a.m. as originally planned.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming after delays, that part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward. That happened last year at the European Championships when the triathlon format was switched because of water quality issues.\n\n\"It's just another situation of the competition,\" said World Triathlon president Marisol Casado, pushing back against the idea that a switch would be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water.\n\nOther swimming events planned in the Seine are the triathlon mixed relay on Monday and the women's and men's marathon swimming events on Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. Marathon swimming could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nBut it's a logistical challenge for triathlon to switch swimming locations given that routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\n\"We are sympathetic,\" Merle said. \"Let's see how it goes.\"\n\nAP writers Barbara Surk in Nice and Devna Bose in Jackson, Mississippi, contributed.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438938137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:27:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:27:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:26:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20240731-paris-olympics-triathlon-seine", "title": "Paris Olympics: Triathlon races to proceed after days of Seine quality concerns", "body": "Following days of delays and concerns regarding the water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will proceed as planned on Wednesday. Organisers confirmed that the latest water tests met the required quality standards.\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organisers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organisers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organisers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day.\n\nFor several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals.\n\nBut others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\"\n\nAnything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\"\n\nBut experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\"\n\nShe noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli.\n\nTwo other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganisers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs.\n\nData released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-438944744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:41:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:41:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:25:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://abc45.com/news/nation-world/olympic-triathletes-will-swim-in-paris-seine-river-days-of-water-quality-concerns-e-coli-sewage-overflow-rain-runoff-athletes", "title": "Olympic triathletes will swim in Paris' Seine River after days of water quality concerns", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.", "source": {"uri": "abc45.com", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "dateEnd": "2024-08-09", "textStart": 3232, "textEnd": 3244}], "sentiment": 0.2, "wgt": 208, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251127533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:00:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:00:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:00:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://time.com/7005536/olympics-mens-triathlon-postponed-seine/", "title": "Men's Olympic Triathlon Postponed Over Seine Water Quality Concerns", "body": "(PARIS) -- Olympics organizers are banking on the sun and scorching temperatures to improve the water quality of the Seine River enough for triathletes to swim in it.\n\nOtherwise, they could be feeling the heat.\n\nConcerns about the Paris river's cleanliness postponed the men's triathlon on Tuesday, with officials hoping the swimming portion of the race will soon be able to go forward in the long-polluted waterway following an expensive cleanup effort.\n\nOrganizers said they will try to hold the men's triathlon Wednesday instead. The women's competition also is scheduled that day, but both will only happen if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is also planned as a backup date.\n\nHowever, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate rescheduling because rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider said. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nRead More: Inside the Billion-Dollar Effort to Clean Up the World's Most Romantic River\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim, leaving uncertainty about its accuracy the day of the race.\n\nParis spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) to improve the water quality in the Seine so the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming event next week could be held in the famed river that runs through the city center. But bacteria levels have remained in flux.\n\nOrganizers were asked if they put the aesthetics of the triathlon over the best interests of athletes.\n\n\"We're living in the 21st century where, unfortunately, there are far more meteorological events that happen that are beyond the control of the organizers,\" Merle said. \"We've seen that we go from heavy rain to extreme heat like today in very few days. So it's actually hard to control how it can affect the quality of a river.\"\n\nParis experienced a downpour during the Olympic opening ceremony Friday, with rain persisting into Saturday. The swimming portion of training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course was canceled on both Sunday and Monday because of concerns over water quality.\n\nOrganizers had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that apparently wasn't sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety. The sun's ultraviolet rays can kill the bacteria and lower levels, and the early part of the week has been hot and sunny.\n\nThe sport's governing body, World Triathlon, its medical team, the IOC and city officials met early Tuesday and decided to postpone.\n\nRead More: How Dangerous Is the Seine for Olympic Athletes?\n\nRider, the triathlete, was on a 4 a.m. run when the delay was announced. A fellow triathlete also out running waved him down.\n\n\"We had a little chat there in the pitch black, at 4 a.m., in the middle of the street, no one around,\" Rider said. \"I just went back to the room and went back to bed.\"\n\nParis Deputy Mayor Pierre Rabadan said \"the trend is improving\" but did not rule out further delays \"if there is an issue tomorrow after the results of the analysis.\"\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\"\n\nBut experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk. \"There's nothing magic about 900,\" said Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida.\n\nOne of four test sites was below the threshold for E. coli on Tuesday, said Merle of Paris 2024. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the threshold.\n\nThe men's triathlon is now scheduled to start at 10:45 a.m. Wednesday, which may make heat more of a factor with the event finishing at the hottest part of the day. World Triathlon is planning to provide ice and water stations along the course for the athletes. The women's race is set to go forward at 8 a.m. as originally planned.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming after delays, that part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward. That happened last year at the European Championships when the triathlon format was switched because of water quality issues.\n\n\"It's just another situation of the competition,\" said World Triathlon president Marisol Casado, pushing back against the idea that a switch would be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water.\n\nOther swimming events planned in the Seine are the triathlon mixed relay on Monday and the women's and men's marathon swimming events on Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. Marathon swimming could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nBut it's a logistical challenge for triathlon to switch swimming locations given that routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\n\"We are sympathetic,\" Merle said. \"Let's see how it goes.\"\n\n___\n\nAP writers Barbara Surk in Nice and Devna Bose in Jackson, Mississippi, contributed.", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@time.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_quality", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "8251680565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:47:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:47:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:45:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-olympic-triathletes-will-swim-in-paris-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality-6151183.html", "title": "Sports News | Olympic Triathletes Will Swim in Paris' Seine River After Days of Concerns About Water Quality | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway.\n\nParis, Jul 31 (AP) After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nAlso Read | Simone Biles Becomes Most Decorated US Olympic Gymnast With 8 Medals, Leads Team USA to Gold in Women's Artistic Team All-Around Event at Paris Olympics 2024.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Colombia Boxer Yeni Marcela Arias Castaneda Cuts Short Preeti Pawar's Campaign in Women's 54 kg Event.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold. {"uri": "2024-07-438654435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:19:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:19:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:53:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.seattlepi.com/sports/article/here-s-what-to-know-about-what-s-next-for-olympic-19607010.php", "title": "Here's what to know about what's next for Olympic triathlon in wake of Seine River water quality", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- The biggest opponent to the swim portion of the triathlon held in the Seine River: E. coli.\n\nBacteria levels in the famed waterway have left organizers of the Paris Games scrambling toward backup plans and even tweaks to the competition in order to make sure they can stage the races. The risky levels of E. coli have already led to swim training to be canceled and on Tuesday the men's competition being pushed back.\n\nOfficials remain hopeful the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted river Wednesday -- or in the coming days. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only happen if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river.\n\nAnother potential hiccup: A forecast of rain beginning Tuesday night and running through Thursday could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming, that portion of the race could potentially be scrapped and only the cycling and running parts would be staged to determine the medal winners.\n\nThere are three triathlon races that will be held at the Paris Games -- the men's and women's competitions, along with a mixed relay. In the triathlon world, the order of events is swimming, biking and running primarily out of safety concerns. The Olympic triathlon distance for the men and women is slightly less than a mile (1.5 kilometers) for the swim, 25 miles (40 kilometers) for cycling and then a 6.2-mile (10K) run.\n\nIt's been part of the Olympic program since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\n\"Pretty crazy to be here after dreaming of it for so long,\" said 27-year-old U.S. triathlete Seth Rider, who took up the sport when he was 6 years old.\n\nLike everyone, triathletes are just waiting on the water-quality reports to come back favorable. In the meantime, they still need to train.\n\nThere are plenty of places to run, of course, even through the busy side streets around the Arrondissements of Paris. High-speed cycling has places, too. But to train for an open-water swim, one option could be the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region.\n\nOr, possibly even a hotel pool. But of course that would mean lots and lots and lots of laps to get in the work they need.\n\nThe women's and men's marathon swimming events are set for Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. For those competitions, backup plans could include relocating, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium. It already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nThat said, it's not easy to just pick up and move the triathlon. One part is predicated on another.\n\nAfter the swim, racers go through a transition area to get to their bikes. After cycling, another transition to prepare for the run. The routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\nShould the river not clear up, the swimming part could always be nixed and the race feature only cycling and running. That was the case last year at the European Championships when the format was switched to a \"duathlon\" because of water-quality issues.\n\nAsked if that might be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water, World Triathlon president Marisol Casado responded: \"It's just another situation of the competition.\"", "source": {"uri": "seattlepi.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Seattle Pi"}, {"uri": "8251624498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:51:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:51:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:41:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13691501/Olympic-triathletes-swim-Paris-Seine-River-days-concerns-water-quality.html", "title": "Olympic triathletes will swim in Paris\u00b4 Seine River after days of...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men\u00b4s race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women\u00b4s competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday\u00b4s Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nA man wipes his face as he walks past reproductions of artworks decorating the banks of the River Seineat the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place. (AP Photo/Vadim Ghirda)\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon\u00b4s water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we\u00b4re very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nA ship sails past reproductions of artworks decorating the banks of the River Seineat the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9776638", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "dateEnd": "2024-08-09", {"uri": "2024-07-439113760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:38:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:38:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:12:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/olympic-women-triathletes-begin-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality/article_f81037ad-fa77-5ad9-b07f-6df49649644f.html", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "A ship sails past reproductions of artworks decorating the banks of the River Seineat the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "2024-07-438651432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:13:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:13:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:52:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/heres-what-to-know-about-whats-next-for-olympic-triathlon-in-wake-of-seine-river/article_c4f030b0-c5ca-5c5a-bbd5-7954acd92c4f.html", "title": "Here's what to know about what's next for Olympic triathlon in wake of Seine River water quality", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- The biggest opponent to the swim portion of the triathlon held in the Seine River: E. coli.\n\nBacteria levels in the famed waterway have left organizers of the Paris Games scrambling toward backup plans and even tweaks to the competition in order to make sure they can stage the races. The risky levels of E. coli have already led to swim training to be canceled and on Tuesday the men's competition being pushed back.\n\nOfficials remain hopeful the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted river Wednesday -- or in the coming days. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only happen if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river.\n\nAnother potential hiccup: A forecast of rain beginning Tuesday night and running through Thursday could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming, that portion of the race could potentially be scrapped and only the cycling and running parts would be staged to determine the medal winners.\n\nHow big is swimming in the triathlon competition?\n\nThere are three triathlon races that will be held at the Paris Games -- the men's and women's competitions, along with a mixed relay. In the triathlon world, the order of events is swimming, biking and running primarily out of safety concerns. The Olympic triathlon distance for the men and women is slightly less than a mile (1.5 kilometers) for the swim, 25 miles (40 kilometers) for cycling and then a 6.2-mile (10K) run.\n\nIt's been part of the Olympic program since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\n\"Pretty crazy to be here after dreaming of it for so long,\" said 27-year-old U.S. triathlete Seth Rider, who took up the sport when he was 6 years old.\n\nWhat can the athletes do during the delays?\n\nLike everyone, triathletes are just waiting on the water-quality reports to come back favorable. In the meantime, they still need to train.\n\nThere are plenty of places to run, of course, even through the busy side streets around the Arrondissements of Paris. High-speed cycling has places, too. But to train for an open-water swim, one option could be the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region.\n\nOr, possibly even a hotel pool. But of course that would mean lots and lots and lots of laps to get in the work they need.\n\nCould the swimming location change?\n\nThe women's and men's marathon swimming events are set for Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. For those competitions, backup plans could include relocating, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium. It already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nThat said, it's not easy to just pick up and move the triathlon. One part is predicated on another.\n\nAfter the swim, racers go through a transition area to get to their bikes. After cycling, another transition to prepare for the run. The routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\nIf no swimming leg, then what?\n\nShould the river not clear up, the swimming part could always be nixed and the race feature only cycling and running. That was the case last year at the European Championships when the format was switched to a \"duathlon\" because of water-quality issues.\n\nAsked if that might be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water, World Triathlon president Marisol Casado responded: \"It's just another situation of the competition.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/sports/olympics/summer/triathlon/olympic-triathalon-women-men-final-results-france-seine-1.7280580", "title": "Victorious Beaugrand thrills home crowd with France's 1st individual Olympic triathlon medal | CBC Sports", "body": "Latest water tests showed compliance with quality standards to swim in Seine\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's triathlon on Wednesday, delighting home fans and clinching the country's first ever Olympic medal in the individual triathlon.\n\nSwitzerland's Julie Derron won silver and Britain's Beth Potter took bronze.\n\nBeaugrand, ranked number one in the world, broke away in the last lap of the run and was fueled to the finish line by ecstatic cheers from crowds lining the streets.\n\nDerron had led for most of the run stage but could not keep up with Beaugrand's pace, while Potter, considered a top contender for gold, had to settle for bronze.\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races went forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the women's and men's triathlon competitions on Wednesday is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($2 billion Cdn) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. "https://i.cbc.ca/1.7280635.1722414526!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/beaugrand-cassandre-240731-1180.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9776638", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "dateEnd": "2024-08-09", "textStart": 3949, "textEnd": 3961}], "sentiment": 0.4039215686274509, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252236528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:25:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:25:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:24:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://abc7.com/post/olympic-triathletes-swim-seine-river-after-days-concerns-water-quality/15126053/", "title": "Olympic triathletes swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "PARIS -- After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River early Wednesday followed by the men a few hours later.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The women's race began under gray skies, with steady rain tapering off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the triathletes stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, a 1.5-kilometer course, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees.\n\nDuring the women's race, the biking portion saw numerous crashes and wipeouts along wet roads, but skies were blue by the time the triathletes began the final leg of the race, a 10-kilometer run. By the time the men's race started, the sun was beating down.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.\n\nParis organizers couldn't contain their delight that their gamble of holding Olympic events in the long-toxic river was paying off, with the astounding scenes of athletes swimming in the Seine's waters.\n\nThe massive infrastructure investment to better manage wastewater has paved the way for Paris' ultimate goal: Allowing Parisians to enjoy the waterway again after more than a century of it being off-limits, with plans to open public pools in its waters from 2025.\n\n\"It's magic,\" said chief Paris Games organizer Tony Estanguet, speaking to French television. \"It's a very important legacy for Parisians to be able to swim from next year in the Seine.\"\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo, who took a much publicized dip in the Seine two weeks ago along with Estanguet and others to ease fears about water quality, said after Beaugrand won the first Olympic gold in the river: \"How special to see her swimming in the Seine, thank you for making us so proud!\"\n\n\"I wasn't very worried about the Seine River because we swam last year and no one was sick after that, so I was confident we could swim today and it would have been a shame if we didn't,\" Beaugrand said. Olympic triathletes participated in a test event in the river last August.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The women began their race at 8 a.m., while the men started at 10:45 a.m. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer John Leicester in Paris contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "abc7.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
