{"uri": "8251864202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:24:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:24:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:23:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/07/31/olympic-triathletes-will-swim-in-paris-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-qual", "title": "Seine water quality controversy: Olympic triathlete event to go ahead", "body": "There had been concerns that bacteria levels were too high in the water, leading to previous postponements.\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward on Wednesday, including the swimming portion in the famed Paris waterway.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organisers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including \u20ac1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early on Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nIt comes after elevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday when the women's competition had been scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall which can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organisers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day.\n\nFor several days, though, they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals - but others can be dangerous.\n\nEven a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhoea and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the faecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\"\n\nAnything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 millilitres is not considered safe or \"sufficient\" - but experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nOn Tuesday, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy on the day of the race.\n\nMerle said on Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She added that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganisers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for 8 and 9 August, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet, as well as Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region and swimmers from local swimming clubs.\n\nData released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 millilitres that day, slightly above the established threshold.", "source": {"uri": "euronews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euronews English"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_quality", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Water quality"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "Seine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bacteria"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gastrointestinal_tract", "type": "wiki", {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarrhea", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Diarrhea"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wastewater", "type": "wiki", "https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/08/61/85/20/1200x675_cmsv2_80935c57-a216-50c7-a188-9cbdd4873766-8618520.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9776638", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "dateEnd": "2024-08-09", "textStart": 3354, "textEnd": 3368}], "sentiment": 0.0980392156862746, {"uri": "2024-07-439308418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:36:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:36:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:19:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/olympic-triathletes-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality/article_f81037ad-fa77-5ad9-b07f-6df49649644f.html", "title": "Olympic triathletes swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River on Wednesday under gray skies that lingered following an early-morning drizzle, followed by the men a few hours later.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady rain tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the triathletes stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, a 1.5-kilometer course, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees.\n\nDuring the women's race, the biking portion saw numerous crashes and wipeouts along wet roads, but skies were blue by the time the triathletes began the final leg of the race, a 10-kilometer run.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo, who took a much publicized dip in the Seine two weeks ago to ease fears about water quality, celebrated Beaugrand's victory.\n\n\"The incredible Cassandre Beaugrand has made history!\" she said in a statement. \"How emotional to see her swimming in the Seine, thank you for making us so proud.\"\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The women began their race at 8 a.m., while the men started at 10:45 a.m. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nAP {"uri": "8252331557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:18:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:18:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:17:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/olympic-triathletes-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality/", "title": "Olympic Triathletes Swim In Seine River After Days Of Concerns About Water Quality", "body": "By KATE BRUMBACK and PAT GRAHAM Associated Press\n\nPARIS (AP) -- After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River early Wednesday, followed by the men a few hours later.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The women's race began under a gray sky, with steady rain tapering off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rain on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the triathletes stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered from the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, a 1.5-kilometer course, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees.\n\nDuring the women's race, the biking portion saw numerous crashes and wipeouts along wet roads, but skies were blue by the time the triathletes began the final leg of the race, a 10-kilometer run. By the time the men's race started, the sun was beating down.\n\nCassandre Beaugrand of France won gold in the women's event, while Julie Derron of Switzerland took silver and Beth Potter of Britain got the bronze medal. Alex Yee of Britain won gold in the men's race, with Hayden Wilde of New Zealand winning silver and L\u00e9o Berg\u00e8re of France taking bronze.\n\nParis organizers couldn't contain their delight that their gamble of holding Olympic events in the long-toxic river was paying off, with the astounding scenes of athletes swimming in the Seine's waters.\n\nThe massive infrastructure investment to better manage wastewater has paved the way for Paris' ultimate goal: allowing Parisians to enjoy the waterway again after more than a century of it being off-limits, with plans to open public pools in its waters from 2025.\n\n\"It's magic,\" said chief Paris Games organizer Tony Estanguet, speaking to French television. \"It's a very important legacy for Parisians to be able to swim from next year in the Seine.\"\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo, who took a much-publicized dip in the Seine two weeks ago along with Estanguet and others to ease fears about water quality, said after Beaugrand won the first Olympic gold in the river: \"How special to see her swimming in the Seine, thank you for making us so proud!\"\n\n\"I wasn't very worried about the Seine River because we swam last year and no one was sick after that, so I was confident we could swim today and it would have been a shame if we didn't,\" Beaugrand said. Olympic triathletes participated in a test event in the river last August.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The women began their race at 8 a.m., while the men started at 10:45 a.m. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rain fell during Friday's opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 1/2 hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8-9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer John Leicester contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "kurv.com", {"uri": "8252051294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:32:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:32:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:31:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/2024-paris-olympics-triathlons-seine-river-pollution/", "title": "Olympic triathlons finally underway after delays due to Seine River E. coli levels", "body": "Paris -- On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlons and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. But the early morning rain could have altered those figures.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the nine-tenths-of-a-mile course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were several wipeouts and spills early in the bike race.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to enable the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters isn't considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nOn July 17, Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took advantage of a few days of dry weather to take make good on her promise to go for a dip in the Seine, after her office announced the river had tested safe for swimming the week before. Hidalgo had promised the Seine would be clean enough to host events for the Games, 100 years after swimming in the river was banned because of the health risks.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", {"uri": "8251167236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:02:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:02:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:33:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13690045/Heres-know-whats-Olympic-triathlon-wake-Seine-River-water-quality.html", "title": "Here's what to know about what's next for Olympic triathlon in wake...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - The biggest opponent to the swim portion of the triathlon held in the Seine River: E. coli.\n\nBacteria levels in the famed waterway have left organizers of the Paris Games scrambling toward backup plans and even tweaks to the competition in order to make sure they can stage the races. The risky levels of E. coli have already led to swim training to be canceled and on Tuesday the men's competition being pushed back.\n\nOfficials remain hopeful the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted river Wednesday - or in the coming days. The women\u00b4s competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only happen if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river.\n\nAnother potential hiccup: A forecast of rain beginning Tuesday night and running through Thursday could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nIf the river isn\u00b4t safe for swimming, that portion of the race could potentially be scrapped and only the cycling and running parts would be staged to determine the medal winners.\n\nThere are three triathlon races that will be held at the Paris Games - the men\u00b4s and women\u00b4s competitions, along with a mixed relay. In the triathlon world, the order of events is swimming, biking and running primarily out of safety concerns. The Olympic triathlon distance for the men and women is slightly less than a mile (1.5 kilometers) for the swim, 25 miles (40 kilometers) for cycling and then a 6.2-mile (10K) run.\n\nA boat sails past reproductions of artworks decorating the banks of the River Seineat the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place. (AP Photo/ Dar Yasin)\n\nIt\u00b4s been part of the Olympic program since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\n\"Pretty crazy to be here after dreaming of it for so long,\" said 27-year-old U.S. triathlete Seth Rider, who took up the sport when he was 6 years old.\n\nLike everyone, triathletes are just waiting on the water-quality reports to come back favorable. In the meantime, they still need to train.\n\nThere are plenty of places to run, of course, even through the busy side streets around the Arrondissements of Paris. High-speed cycling has places, too. But to train for an open-water swim, one option could be the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region.\n\nOr, possibly even a hotel pool. But of course that would mean lots and lots and lots of laps to get in the work they need.\n\nThe women\u00b4s and men\u00b4s marathon swimming events are set for Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. For those competitions, backup plans could include relocating, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium. It already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nThat said, it's not easy to just pick up and move the triathlon. One part is predicated on another.\n\nAfter the swim, racers go through a transition area to get to their bikes. After cycling, another transition to prepare for the run. The routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\nShould the river not clear up, the swimming part could always be nixed and the race feature only cycling and running. That was the case last year at the European Championships when the format was switched to a \"duathlon\" because of water-quality issues.\n\nAsked if that might be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water, World Triathlon president Marisol Casado responded: \"It\u00b4s just another situation of the competition.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nA man wipes his face as he walks past reproductions of artworks decorating the banks of the River Seineat the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Paris, France. The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place. (AP Photo/Vadim Ghirda)\n\nTechnicians remove the pontoon for the start of the triathlon events after the event was postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, at the Pont Alexandre III bridge in Paris, France. {"uri": "8251614330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:29:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:29:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:28:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/seine-river-ap-paris-anne-hidalgo-european-union-b2588573.html", "title": "Olympic triathletes will swim in Paris' Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "8251860670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:21:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:21:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:20:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/olympic-women-triathletes-begin-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality/article_6ca7b59b-9f2a-567e-a970-b9cfe12ce749.html", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.bnd.com/sports/article290598574.html", "title": "Olympic triathletes set to swim Seine after water quality tests show river safe", "body": "July 30 (UPI) -- Following days of uncertainty over the water quality of Paris' famed Seine River, Olympic organizers said recent tests showed that the triathlon events set for Wednesday morning can go ahead as planned.\n\nThe women's triathlon event is scheduled for 8 a.m. Wednesday followed by the men's triathlon at 10:45 a.m.\n\n\"We will swim,\" World Triathlon said Wednesday morning in a post on X.\n\nThe announcement comes after water analyses received at 3:20 a.m. local time Wednesday showed levels compliant with World Triathlon standards, the sport's governing body and Paris Olympics organizers said in a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was originally scheduled for 8 a.m. Tuesday but was postponed following failed water quality tests of the Seine River where athletes are to compete in the swim portion of the three-leg race.\n\nConcerns over whether the triathlons would take place had long been stoked heading into the Olympics as swimming in the Seine has been banned for a century.\n\nOver the course of nearly a decade, some $1.5 billion has been spent to improve the environmental and sanitary quality of the water in the Seine to make it swimmable in the long term and, on the short term, an Olympic venue this week.\n\nAs recently as last month, a report was published showing the river was still too unsafe for swimming.\n\nBut efforts continued, and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip in the river two weeks ago to show it was on track for good showing at the Olympics.\n\nHowever, heavy rains on Friday and Saturday resulted in a drop in the river's water quality, forcing organizers to postpone the men's race on Tuesday.\n\nFriday was slated as a contingency date.\n\nThe triathlon is not the only event using the Seine for Olympic competition.\n\nThe women's 10-km marathon swimming event is scheduled to take place 7:30 a.m. on Aug. 8, with the men's event scheduled for the same time the following day.\n\nFor both events, athletes are to swim a forward on Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organisers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river.\n\nHeavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters on Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim.\n\nSubscribe free to our weekly newsletter for exclusive and original coverage from ITV News. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the {"uri": "8251874497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:32:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:32:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:31:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-olympic-women-triathletes-begin-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality-6151668.html", "title": "Sports News | Olympic Women Triathletes Begin Swim in Seine River After Days of Concerns About Water Quality | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nParis, Jul 31 (AP) On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on.\n\nAlso Read | Premier League 2024-25: Chelsea Sign Denmark Goalkeeper Filip Jorgensen From Villarreal.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nAlso Read | Taapsee Pannu Enjoys Dinner Date With Husband Mathias Boe During Paris Olympics 2024 (View Pics).\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs. Data released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 milliliters that day, slightly above the established threshold. {"uri": "8252324664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:14:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:14:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:13:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1343006", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons were held Wednesday as the athletes dove into the Seine River to swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes for the women's triathlon splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nCassandre Beaugrand of France won the women's race -- and the country's first-ever Olympic medal in the individual triathlon -- finishing the run on top of the Pont Alexandre III bridge and collapsing to the ground in exhaustion and exhilaration.\n\n\"I have no doubts about the quality of the Seine. We've swum in worse water,\" Beaugrand said after her victory, adding that scrapping the swim and holding a duathlon -- the organizers' last resort if the river had been too dirty -- would have been \"shameful\" for the sport.\n\nBeaugrand's time of 1 hour, 54 minutes, 55 seconds edged Julie Derron of Switzerland by six seconds. Britain's Beth Potter captured bronze.\n\nBritain's Alex Yee won gold in the men's triathlon. New Zealand's Hayden Wilde won silver, and Leo Bergere of France took the bronze.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including $1.5 billion in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday that the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. But the early morning rain could have altered those figures.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" said Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5-kilometer course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were several wipeouts and spills early in the bike race.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course were canceled Sunday and Monday due to the water conditions.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals, but others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nWorld Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21\u00bd hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit, and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nThe Associated Press and Reuters contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-439230917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:32:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:32:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.wlwt.com/article/olympic-triathletes-swim-in-seine-river/61747970", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River on Wednesday under gray skies that lingered following an early-morning drizzle.The athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady rain tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.The decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including $1.5 billion in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.The organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"As they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered from the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5-kilometer course.After swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were numerous crashes and wipeouts along the wet roads. There were blue skies when the triathletes began the final portion of the race, a 10-kilometer run.France's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.Elevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.The water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.Every day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.High levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.Daily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.Plus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.Merle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.Organizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nAfter days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River on Wednesday under gray skies that lingered following an early-morning drizzle.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady rain tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including $1.5 billion in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered from the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5-kilometer course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were numerous crashes and wipeouts along the wet roads. There were blue skies when the triathletes began the final portion of the race, a 10-kilometer run.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.", {"uri": "8251061111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:09:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:09:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:08:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.oregonlive.com/sports/2024/07/paris-olympics-mens-triathlon-postponed-due-to-polluted-river-siene.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Men's triathlon postponed due to polluted River Siene", "body": "The men's triathlon race, scheduled for Tuesday morning, has been postponed due unsafe water pollution levels in the River Seine, Olympics organizers said.\n\nThe levels of the E. coli and other bacteria remain too high for swimming, officials said, and the race was pushed back a day to Wednesday morning. The race is scheduled to take place hours after the women's triathlon is completed.\n\n\"Despite the improvement on the water quality levels in the last hours, the readings at some points of the swim course are above acceptable levels,\" World Triathlon, the international governing body for the sport at the Olympics, said in a statement.\n\nOfficials said heavy rain on Friday and Saturday, which generally cause bacteria levels in the Seine to rise, are the culprit. Organizers are hoping the sun - which can help deactivate bacteria - and scorching temperatures (the temperature is expected to reach the high 90s on Tuesday) will help improve water quality enough for the races to be held on Wednesday.\n\nPollution in the river has been a longstanding problem. Prior to the Olympics, the city of Paris and French government spent nearly $1.5 billion to clean up the Seine. The project retrofitted the antiquated sewer system which overflows into the river during heavy rains. The hope is the work would allow the triathlons and long distance swimming events could be safely held in the famous river that runs through the city center.\n\nIf bacteria levels remain high on Wednesday, organizers said they would look to hold the races on Friday. If the river isn't safe for swimming after more delays, the swimming portion of part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251659534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:23:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:23:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-31/paris-olympic-games-triathlon-river-water-quality-seine/104164254", "title": "Olympic triathletes given all clear to swim in River Seine despite days of water quality concerns", "body": "Olympic officials have given the River Seine the green light to host the men's and women's Olympic triathlon races, despite days of concerns about water quality\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organisers and athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early Wednesday, local time, the latest water tests complied with quality standards.\n\nABC Sport is live blogging every day of the Paris Olympics\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been cancelled due to poor water quality on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organisers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day.\n\nFor several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous.\n\nEven a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhoea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli.\n\nWorld Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\"\n\nAnything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 millilitres is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21-and-a-half hours before decisions are made about the swim.\n\nThat leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\"\n\nShe noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\nOrganisers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for August 8 and 9, could be relocated if needed to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet; Marc Guillaume, the top government official for the Paris region; and swimmers from local swimming clubs.\n\nData released last week show that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie were at 985 units per 100 millilitres that day, slightly above the established threshold.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Wednesday as Seine passes water tests", "body": "General view of the Seine River and Eiffel Tower as the 2024 Olympics men's individual triathlon was postponed as pollution levels remained too high on Tuesday.\n\nImage: Reuters/Fabrizio Bensch\n\nOrganisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8am Paris time, with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45am, immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent \u20ac1.4bn of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5am combined with a
