{"uri": "8252113075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:10:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:10:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20240731/p2g/00m/0sp/054000c", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River on Wednesday under gray skies that lingered following an early-morning drizzle.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady rain tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5-kilometer course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were numerous crashes and wipeouts along the wet roads. There were blue skies when the triathletes began the final portion of the race, a 10-kilometer run.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aurelie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.", tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards, allowing the swim legs to be held in the river.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river had pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition is also scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same {"uri": "8252053586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:33:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:33:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:32:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/olympic-women-triathletes-begin-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality/article_ebe12990-a585-520a-98fa-e3445197cec3.html", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "Flora Duffy, of Bermuda, competes during the women's individual triathlon competition at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Wednesday, July 31, 2024, in Paris, France.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- After days of water-quality concerns caused by heavy rains last week put the swimming portion of the Olympic triathlons in doubt, the women dove into the Seine River on Wednesday under gray skies that lingered following an early-morning drizzle.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady rain tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions was a big deal for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. That came after days of uncertainty following heavy rains on Friday and Saturday.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5-kilometer course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were numerous crashes and wipeouts along the wet roads. There were blue skies when the triathletes began the final portion of the race, a 10-kilometer run.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's event, while Switzerland's Julie Derron took silver and Great Britain's Beth Potter got the bronze medal.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nAP The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. But the early morning rain could have altered those figures.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. There were several wipeouts and spills early in the bike race.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can {"uri": "8251977960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:43:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:43:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/olympics/youre-at-the-mercy-of-mother-nature-triathlon-gets-underway-in-seine-despite-pollution-concerns/a1572205762.html", "title": "'You're at the mercy of Mother Nature' - Triathlon gets underway in Seine despite pollution concerns", "body": "On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway today as the women dove into the Seine river to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on and heading into the river with the Eiffel Tower in the background.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including \u20ac1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early this morning the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards. But the early morning rain could have altered those figures.\n\n\"The problem is always worse when there's a heavy rainfall, because it kind of overwhelms the pipes and you also get all the runoff from the street. All that lands in the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to try to improve the quality of the water. But the truth is you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats that line the banks of the river. Spectators watched and cheered form the stands set up along the side and from the bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, taking about 22 minutes to complete the 1.5km course.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes emerged from the water and ran up a set of stairs to jump on their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. There were several wipeouts and spills early in the bike race.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organisers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganisers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Auguest 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438726015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:50:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:50:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:48:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/paris-olympics-seine-river-pollution-dirty-sewers-1932233", "title": "How $1.5B plan to clean Seine and save Paris' 14th century sewers failed", "body": "A $1.5 billion initiative to revitalize Paris' ancient sewer system and make the Seine river swimmable for the 2024 Summer Olympics has all but collapsed, raising doubts about the river's readiness for swimming competitions.\n\nConcerns about the river's cleanliness led to the postponement of the men's triathlon on Tuesday. Officials hope the swimming portion of the event can soon proceed following the expensive cleanup effort.\n\nOrganizers plan to hold the men's triathlon on Wednesday instead. The women's competition is also scheduled for the same day, but both events will only happen if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is the backup date.\n\nHeavy rain and thunderstorms are in the forecast from Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate the rescheduling. Rain, like the downpour that dampened Friday's Opening Ceremony, generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider told the Associated Press. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon, and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nSwimming has been off-limits in the long-polluted Seine for more than a century. In preparation for the Games, the city promised to clean its famed river to demonstrate that hosting the Olympics would provide benefits to skeptical Parisians.\n\nThe city invested millions in building a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and prevent untreated waste from flowing into the Seine, renovating the sewage system, and upgrading water treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo has been a vocal advocate for the cleanup, even taking a symbolic swim in the Seine to demonstrate her confidence in the project's success.\n\n\"Our objective is an Olympic legacy,\" said Pierre Rabadan, the deputy mayor overseeing the project. \"That you and I or whoever happens to be in Paris can swim in the Seine.\"\n\nSwimming could be scrapped\n\nDespite those best efforts, Mother Nature intervened at the worst possible time, delivering torrential rain to central Paris all day on Friday, before and during the Opening ceremony and persisting into Saturday. Training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course were canceled on both Sunday and Monday due to water quality concerns.\n\nOrganizers had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that was not sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety on Tuesday.\n\n\"Despite the improvement in water quality levels in the last hours, the readings at some points of the swim course are still above the acceptable limits,\" organizers said, stressing that their \"priority is the health of the athletes.\"\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming after continued delays, that part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward. Something similar happened last year at the European Championships in Madrid, when the triathlon format was switched due to water quality issues in the Casa de Campo lake.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure E. coli levels, which indicate sewage contamination. While most E. coli strains are harmless and live in the intestines of healthy people and animals, some can be dangerous. Swallowing contaminated water can cause diarrhea and illnesses like urinary tract or intestinal infections.\n\nWorld Triathlon, the international governing body for the multi-discipline sport, has water safety guidelines that, along with a 2006 European Union directive, set the safe limit for E. coli at 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters. On Tuesday, one of the four test sites was below this threshold. However, two sites were just above the limit, and one site had much higher levels, ranging from 980 to 1,553.\n\nSome experts and residents remain skeptical. A recent poll by the French market-research firm Ifop found that 70% of respondents viewed the Seine negatively, describing it as dirty, polluted and smelly.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/07/30/sports/sports-breaking/triathlon-races-to-go-ahead-as-seine-passes-water-quality-tests/", "title": "Triathlon races to go ahead as Seine passes water quality tests | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Athletes swims in the river Seine at the start of the race as the Eiffel Tower is seen.\n\nPARIS >> Organisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place today but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute today had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. combined with a discussion between experts on overnight weather, according to Paris 2024.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star Advertiser"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@staradvertiser.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-07-438771688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:57:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:57:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:56:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://ici.radio-canada.ca/rci/en/news/2092834/seine-water-quality-triathlon", "title": "Men's Olympic triathlon postponed due to pollution concerns in Seine", "body": "The men's Olympic triathlon planned for Tuesday has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place.\n\nOrganizers said they will try to hold the men's triathlon Wednesday instead. The women's competition is also scheduled on Wednesday, but both are subject to water tests. Friday is also planned as a backup date.\n\nBut Meteo-France, the French weather service, was forecasting storms Tuesday night, light rain Wednesday afternoon and storms Thursday, which could complicate rescheduling the events.\n\nHeavy rains generally cause levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the Seine to rise. Paris experienced a downpour during the Olympic opening ceremony Friday, with rain continuing into Saturday.\n\nThe swimming portion of training events, meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course, was cancelled on both Sunday and Monday because of concerns over water quality.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's triathlon followed a meeting early Tuesday morning that included the sport's governing body, World Triathlon, its medical team and city officials.\n\nTriathlon Canada high performance director Phil Dunne noted safety as the top priority when dealing with uncontrollable variables in any open water event.\n\nWe have full confidence in World Triathlon and Paris 2024's mitigation plans to prioritize the health and safety of our athletes, while continuously monitoring the water conditions in Paris and developing appropriate plans that ensure the events are executed safely and as anticipated, he said.\n\nCanadians Tyler Mislawchuk and Olympic rookie Charles Paquet are among 55 athletes scheduled to race.\n\nMislawchuk of Oak Bluff, Man., would be making his third Olympic appearance after placing 15th in 2016 (Rio) and 2021 (Tokyo). Paquet, who hails from Port-Cartier, Que., was seventh in an Olympic qualification race in Italy two months ago after placing a career-best fifth in a World Triathlon Championship Series race in Yokohama, Japan.\n\nSimon Whitfield earned Canada's only two Olympic triathlon medals, when the sport made its 2000 Olympic debut in Sydney and eight years later in Beijing.\n\nOrganizers and city officials had expressed confidence that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed in the days that followed, but that apparently wasn't sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety.\n\nWATCH | Flushing the Seine of fecal bacteria before Olympic athletes dive in:\n\nSome strains of E. coli can be dangerous\n\nParis made an enormous effort to improve the water quality in the long-polluted Seine so the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming event in August could be held in the famed river that runs through the city centre. But bacteria levels have remained in flux.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of fecal bacteria known as E. coli, with a safe limit of 900 colony-forming units per 100 millilitres determined by European rules. Monitoring group Eau de Paris releases data each Friday, but it is updated only through the previous Tuesday.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming cost just over $2 billion. They include the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo very publicly took a swim in the river two weeks ago, along with Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet, and the top government official for the Paris region, Marc Guillaume, along with swimmers from local swimming clubs.\n\nData released last week shows that E. coli levels at the Bras Marie area of the Seine were at 985 units per 100 millilitres that day, slightly above the established threshold.\n\nOther swimming events planned in the Seine are the triathlon mixed relay on Aug. 5 and women's and men's marathon swimming events Aug. 8 and Aug. 9.", {"uri": "8252049356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:30:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:30:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:30:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2024-07-31-olympic-triathlon-races-under-way-as-seine-passes-water-tests-ending-days-of-uncertainty/", "title": "Olympic triathlon races get under way as Seine passes water tests", "body": "The triathlon was given the green light to go ahead in the early hours of Wednesday morning.\n\nAthletes dived into the Seine on Wednesday for the Olympic women's triathlon after water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe triathlon, conceived as a central showpiece of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge at the heart of the French capital and takes athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past monuments including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nJust as overnight rain was easing, the women began their competition at 8am, the triathlon offering spectacular views as they swam in the Seine before racing their bikes into the very heart of Paris.\n\nA handful of athletes, however, crashed off their bicycles after slipping on the wet cobblestones of the Champs-Elysees.\n\nRead more: Olympic Games Paris 2024\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but, after the river failed water quality tests, it was postponed to 10.45am on Wednesday, immediately after the women's race.\n\nThe races going ahead will be a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely from day to day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5am and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5.45am on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries began the contest at 8am, with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nRead more: Faster, Higher, Stronger - Together: The very best images from Day Four of 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nParis has spent $1.51-billion (R27.9-million) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water would not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.", "source": {"uri": "dailymaverick.co.za", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-438652649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:15:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:15:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:04:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/07/30/olympic-triathlon-postponed-seine-e-coli-water-quality/", "title": "Olympic men's triathlon postponed due to E. coli in Seine River", "body": "The Olympic men's triathlon was postponed Tuesday due to unsafe levels of E. coli bacteria in the Seine River.\n\nOrganizers rescheduled the event for Wednesday, the same day the women's triathlon is supposed to take place. However, the situation remains in flux as authorities monitor water quality in the Seine.\n\n\"I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid,\" American triathlete Seth Rider said after the delay.\n\nParis Olympic organizers spent $1.5 billion trying to clean up the Seine in the years before the Games. Swimming in the river had been banned for over a century because the water was not safe. However, French leaders insisted that it would be ready for the triathlon and the open-water marathon swimming events, scheduled for next week.\n\nBut a downpour last Friday and into Saturday dropped the water quality in the Seine, which is still heavily subject to meteorological events. The first sign of trouble came Sunday when organizers canceled a planned practice swim.\n\n\"Unfortunately, there are far more meteorological events that happen that are beyond the control of the organizers,\" Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, said Tuesday. \"We've seen that we go from heavy rain to extreme heat like today in very few days. So it's actually hard to control how it can affect the quality of a river.\"\n\nMore rain was expected in Paris beginning Tuesday night and continuing into Thursday. If the triathlon cannot happen Wednesday, organizers also considered Friday as a possible backup date.", "source": {"uri": "nydailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily News"}, "authors": The men's Olympic triathlon has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine River, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- After days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go forward Wednesday with a swim in the famed Paris waterway, organizers said.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the Seine swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. {"uri": "8251659648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:23:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:23:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:22:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3036161-seine-river-cleared-for-olympic-triathlon-despite-water-concerns", "title": "Seine River Cleared for Olympic Triathlon Despite Water Concerns | Sports-Games", "body": "After delays due to elevated bacteria levels, the Seine River will host the men's and women's Olympic triathlon races. The races were postponed amid efforts to ensure water quality met safety standards. Officials invested \u20ac1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements to clean the Seine, and latest tests confirm compliance with quality standards.\n\nAfter days of delays over concerns about water quality in the Seine River, the Olympic triathlon races will proceed Wednesday with a swim in the iconic Paris waterway.\n\nThe decision is a major win for the city, Olympic organizers, and athletes. Officials invested \u20ac1.4 billion in infrastructure to clean the Seine, insisting it would be safe for both the triathlon and next week's marathon swimming events.\n\nLatest tests, as of early Wednesday, confirmed the water meets quality standards. Elevated bacteria levels had postponed the men's race, initially scheduled for Tuesday, to Wednesday, the same day as the women's race. Rainfall had exacerbated wastewater runoff into the river, complicating efforts to maintain water quality.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli, a bacteria indicating sewage contamination, were a primary concern. While most E. coli strains are harmless, some can cause serious illness if ingested through contaminated water. Water quality tests measured fecal bacteria levels, with safe swimming conditions set at below 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters.\n\nDespite uncertainties, confidence remained high among organizers, even as they withheld detailed public data on bacteria levels. Results indicated some test sites were near acceptable thresholds, and organizers hoped that recent heat would improve water quality.\n\nThe marathon swimming events could be moved to another venue if needed. Significant investments included a basin to manage rainwater, infrastructure renovation, and wastewater treatment upgrades. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo and other officials recently swam in the Seine to demonstrate their confidence in the river's safety, though data showed E. coli levels slightly above the threshold.", {"uri": "8251910363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:58:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:58:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:58:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/paris-olympics-triathlon-races-underway-as-seine-passes-water-tests/20240731.htm", "title": "Triathlon races underway as Seine passes water tests", "body": "IMAGE: Swimmer dive into the Seine as the women's Individual Triathlon race commences at Alexander III Bridge, Paris, France, on Wednesday. Photograph: Lisa Leutner/Reuters\n\nAthletes dived into the Seine on Wednesday for the Olympic women's triathlon after water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until later on Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nThe women began their race at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), just as overnight rain was easing.\n\nThe races going ahead will be a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nThe triathlon, conceived as a central showpiece of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge and takes athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past monuments including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\n'PUPPET SHOW'\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n($1 = 0.9240 euros)\n\nTHE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", {"uri": "8251928348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:10:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:10:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:09:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/olympics-triathlon-races-underway-as-seine-passes-water-tests/85528591", "title": "Olympics-Triathlon-Races underway as Seine passes water tests", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) -Athletes dived into the Seine on Wednesday for the Olympic women's triathlon after water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until later on Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nThe women began their race at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), just as overnight rain was easing.\n\nThe races going ahead will be a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nThe triathlon, conceived as a central showpiece of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge and takes athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past monuments including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\n'PUPPET SHOW'\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n($1 = 0.9240 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Helen Reid; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", {"uri": "8251931209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:12:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:12:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:11:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.newindianexpress.com/sport/olympics/2024/Jul/31/olympic-women-triathletes-begin-swim-in-seine-river-after-days-of-concerns-about-water-quality-2", "title": "Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality", "body": "PARIS: On a morning that started with rain, the Olympic triathlons got underway Wednesday as the women dove into the Seine River to start the swim after days of delays and uncertainty over water quality concerns.\n\nThe athletes began near the Pont Alexandre III, a bridge that spans the famed Paris waterway. The steady drizzle tapered off just as the athletes splashed into the water. Some of the triathletes dunked their swim goggles in the Seine before putting them on.\n\nThe decision to go ahead with the swim for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organizers and the athletes. Officials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe organisers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiariSe themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. {"uri": "8251849278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:12:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:12:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:12:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5670270/2024/07/31/olympic-triathlon-seine-water-quality/", "title": "Olympic triathlon will take place amid Seine water quality concerns", "body": "The River Seine has been deemed clean enough to hold the men's and women's Olympic triathlon today (Wednesday) after officials postponed the men's event due to elevated bacteria levels in the water.\n\nParis 2024 confirmed the decision in the early hours of Wednesday morning, following a meeting on the water quality which took place at 3.30am local time. \"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" a Paris 2024 statement read. The women's event started at 7am local time, with the men due to begin at 9.45am.\n\nThe men's event, originally scheduled for Tuesday, was to be moved to Wednesday -- following the women's triathlon on the same day -- if conditions improved. Training sessions in the Seine were canceled on Sunday and Monday when organizers deemed pollution levels too high.\n\n\"We will swim,\" World Triathlon said in a post on X in the early hours of Wednesday morning.\n\nEvery morning at 3:30 a.m., Paris 2024, the DRIEAT, which is the regional environmental agency, the City of Paris and the prefecture of the Ile-de-France region are involved in carrying out water quality tests. They relay the results to the technical and medical officials with World Triathlon and World Aquatics.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 30 July at 3:30am ... Paris 2024 and World Triathlon have made the decision to postpone the men's triathlon event which was due to be held on 30 July at 8am,\" a joint statement Tuesday from Paris 2024 organizers and the sport's governing body said.\n\nFriday was previously set to be a contingency day for any further issues, and World Triathlon said the event could be reduced to a duathlon (bike and run) if swimming was not safely possible.\n\nThe recent spike in E. coli levels in the river could largely be traced to heavy rain around the city in recent days, which hampered Friday's opening ceremony. Organizers hoped warm and sunny conditions could lower the E. coli and enterococci concentration levels and salvage race plans.\n\nThe Seine's water quality has been an ongoing storyline ahead of and during the Paris Olympics, as many resources, including billions of dollars of technology, have been poured into making the river suitable for competition. The Seine had previously been illegal to swim in since 1923.\n\nParis mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river on July 17, fulfilling her promise to jump in and showcase the water's cleanliness ahead of the Games.\n\nOne American triathlete, Seth Rider, said he turned to the unconventional measure of not washing his hands after using the bathroom to increase his E. coli threshold in preparation for swimming in the Seine.\n\n\"We know that there's going to be some E. coli exposure, so I just try to increase my E. coli threshold by exposing myself to a bit of E. coli in your day-to-day life,\" he said.\n\nFellow American triathlete Taylor Spivey said Saturday: \"Hopefully we get a swim, bike and run, because I don't swim this much to just run and bike.\"\n\nThe Seine is also scheduled to host the mixed team relay event on Aug. 5 and the marathon swimming races (6.2 miles) on Aug. 8 and Aug. 9 before the Para-triathlon is set to take place there Sept. 1-2.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", {"uri": "8252056592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:35:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:35:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:34:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/sports/triathletes-take-plunge-as-seine-clears-for-paris-olympic-swim/news", "title": "Triathletes take plunge as Seine clears for Paris Olympic swim", "body": "On a rainy morning, the Olympic triathlons kicked off with the women diving into the Seine River after days of delays due to water quality concerns.\n\nStarting near the iconic Pont Alexandre III, the drizzle eased as the athletes entered the water, with the Eiffel Tower providing a striking backdrop.\n\nSome triathletes dipped their goggles into the Seine before donning them and starting their swim.\n\nThe decision to proceed with the swim is a significant victory for the city, Olympic organizers, and the athletes.\n\nOfficials implemented an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine.\n\nThey have been adamant that the swimming portion of the triathlon and next week's marathon swimming events could be held safely in the river.\n\nOrganizers said early Wednesday that the latest water tests met quality standards, though early morning rain could have affected those results.\n\n\"The problem is always worse with heavy rainfall because it overwhelms the pipes and causes runoff from the streets to enter the Seine,\" explained Dr. Nicole Iovine, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Florida. \"They've done a lot to improve water quality, but ultimately, you're at the mercy of Mother Nature.\"\n\nAs they swam, the women stayed close to the barges and boats lining the riverbanks. Spectators watched and cheered from stands along the side and from bridges spanning the waterway. Reigning Olympic champion Flora Duffy of Bermuda was the first out of the water, completing the 1.5-kilometer course in about 22 minutes.\n\nAfter swimming two laps in the Seine, the athletes ran up a set of stairs to transition to their bikes for a ride through the rain-soaked streets of Paris, including the iconic Champs-Elysees. Several wipeouts and spills occurred early in the bike race.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race, originally scheduled for Tuesday, to Wednesday, the same day as the women's competition. The men were slated to start about three hours after the women's race. Test events meant to familiarize athletes with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall, which can lead to wastewater runoff into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony and continued through Saturday.\n\nEven as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they expressed confidence that the swims would proceed as planned the following day. For several days, they did not publicly release data on E. coli and other bacteria levels that influenced their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli can indicate sewage contamination. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals, but others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can cause diarrhea and infections in the urinary tract or intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure E. coli levels. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive provide a range from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe. Experts emphasize that these numbers are guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, Paris 2024's director of sports, said Tuesday that water samples are taken 21.5 hours before decisions are made about the swim, leaving some uncertainty about their accuracy on the day of the race.\n\nMerle noted that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold for triathlon.\" She mentioned that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the E. coli threshold, while two sites were just above the limit, and one was more elevated, with levels ranging from 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and heat have a strong impact on water quality,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave affecting much of France on Tuesday would improve water quality enough for the swims to proceed.\n\nOrganizers have said that if needed, the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439314518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:41:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:41:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:05:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.aol.com/olympic-triathlon-goes-ahead-officials-080545180.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon goes ahead after officials give the green light over Seine water quality", "body": "Olympic triathlon goes ahead after officials give the green light over Seine water quality\n\nKyle Feldscher, CNN\n\nJuly 31, 2024 at 10:05 AM\n\nThe triathlon competitions are up and running in Paris on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier.\n\nMore rain came into Paris overnight but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe women's race had been marked by bike crashes on the wet streets of Paris. In the cycling portion of the race, several athletes fell after slipping on the slippery roads. Vittoria Lopes of Brazil was among the leaders when she fell but fell out of contention.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand eventually was crowned women's triathlon Olympic champion on home soil, roared across the finish line by a boisterous French crowd that broke out into a rendition 'La Marseillaise.'\n\nThe men's race is set to begin at 4:45 a.m. ET.\n\nRains impacting water quality\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris over the weekend, drenching Friday's opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for a second straight day on Monday after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that Tuesday's race would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) has been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races begin with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nA mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/07/31/races-underway-as-seine-passes-water-tests/", "title": "Races underway as Seine passes water tests", "body": "Athletes dived into the Seine on Wednesday for the Olympic women's triathlon after water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe triathlon, conceived as a central showpiece of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge at the heart of the French capital and takes athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past monuments including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nJust as overnight rain was easing, the women began their competition at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), the triathlon offering spectacular views as they swam in the Seine before racing their bikes into the very heart of Paris.\n\nA handful of athletes, however, crashed off their bicycles after slipping on the wet cobblestones of the Champs-Elysees.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but, after the river failed water quality tests, it was postponed to 10:45 a.m. (0845 GMT) on Wednesday, immediately after the women's race.\n\nThe races going ahead will be a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nGREEN LIGHT\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's {"uri": "8250755489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:41:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:41:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:40:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://nationalpost.com/news/mens-olympic-triathlon-postponed-in-paris-over-seine-water-quality", "title": "Seine water quality fails tests again, delaying the men's triathlon", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nHowever, storms or rain are forecast Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate efforts to reschedule the events because rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nParis experienced a downpour during the Olympic opening ceremony Friday, with rain persisting into Saturday. The swimming portion of training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course was canceled on both Sunday and Monday because of concerns over water quality.\n\n\"There are unfortunate meteorological events outside of our control,\" said Aurelie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports. \"But otherwise the project is still very strong. When we see the impact on the quality and the legacy that we can leave also to the Parisians, we all feel extremely proud of what we've done so far.\"\n\nThe delays come after Olympic organizers and city officials had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that apparently wasn't sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety. The sun's ultraviolet rays can kill the bacteria and lower levels, and Tuesday is hot and sunny.", "source": {"uri": "nationalpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "National Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seine", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Seine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games_ceremony", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Olympic Games ceremony"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_quality", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Water quality"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meteorology", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Meteorology"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Bacteria"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultraviolet", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Ultraviolet"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Triathlon", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Triathlon", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Duathlon", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Duathlon", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally_Challenged", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally Challenged", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://smartcdn.gprod.postmedia.digital/nationalpost/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/paris-olympics-triathlon.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9776638", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.07450980392156858, "wgt": 176, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251862311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:23:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:23:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:22:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/triathlon-races-to-go-ahead-as-seine-passes-water-quality-tests-2574248-2024-07-31", "title": "Olympics: Triathlon races to go ahead as Seine passes water quality tests", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics organizers have given the green light for the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to proceed on Wednesday, following recent water tests in the Seine river that showed reduced bacteria levels. This decision ends days of uncertainty caused by heavy rains, which had raised concerns about the viability of swimming in central Paris. Initially scheduled for Tuesday, the men's triathlon was postponed to Wednesday after the river failed to meet water quality standards. The confirmation that the races would go ahead was a relief for athletes, teams, and Paris authorities, who have promised a swimmable\n\nSeine as a lasting legacy of the Games, with the triathlon serving as a prominent test. \"We are thrilled to receive this news,\" said Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, in a statement to Reuters. \"Now that the event is confirmed, we can fully focus on the competition.\" Despite overnight rain, the races were approved to proceed. Organizers based their decision on the analysis of river samples collected at 5 a.m. the previous day, along with expert discussions on weather conditions, according to Paris 2024. Showers resumed at around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, adding to the challenge of the bike stage, which includes sharp turns and cobbled road sections.\n\nParis Olympics 2024: India Schedule | Full Coverage | Medal Tally\n\nThe triathlon, a central showcase of the Paris Olympics, starts and ends at the Alexandre III bridge, with the route taking athletes along part of the Champs-Elysees and past landmarks like the Musee d'Orsay. The women's race, featuring 55 competitors from 34 countries, will begin at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT). Among the top contenders for gold are France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, who will dive into the Seine side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge. The men's event will follow at 10:45 a.m. \"The latest water analyses, received at 3:20 a.m., have been deemed compliant by World Triathlon, allowing the triathlon competitions to proceed,\" stated Paris 2024 and World Triathlon.\n\nPARIS WATER QUALITY\n\nParis has invested 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) in wastewater infrastructure to manage sewage and minimize spillage into the river. Earlier this month, Mayor Anne Hidalgo even swam in the Seine to assure the public of its safety. The last-minute postponement of the men's race on Tuesday caused frustration among some athletes. \"If the priority was the health of the athletes, this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" wrote Belgium's Marten Van Riel on World Triathlon's Instagram page. \"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe risk that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was
