{"uri": "8251067858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:13:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:13:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:13:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.dailybreeze.com/2024/07/30/polluted-river-seine-forces-olympic-triathlon-postponement/", "title": "Polluted River Seine forces Olympic triathlon postponement", "body": "PARIS - Paris 2024 officials postponed the men's Olympic triathlon because athlete health concerns Tuesday morning less than five hours before the event was supposed to start with the swim in River Seine.\n\nThe decision was made after a 3:30 a.m. (local time) meeting between Paris 2024, the International Olympic Committee, World Triathlon, City of Paris and Meteo Paris officials during which local health officials revealed that tests revealed dangerous levels of bacteria such as E.coli.\n\n\"Tests carried out in the Seine today revealed water quality levels that did not provide sufficient guarantees to allow the event to be held,\" Paris 2024 officials said in official communication later Tuesday.\n\n\"We're living in the 21st century where, unfortunately, there are far more meteorological events that happen that are beyond the control of the organizers,\" Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, said. \"We've seen that we go from heavy rain to extreme heat like today in very few days. So it's actually hard to control how it can affect the quality of a river.\"\n\nThe postponement is an embarrassing setback for Paris officials who had promoted a cleaned up Seine as a centerpiece of what they and the IOC had described as the most environmentally friendly Games in Olympic history.\n\nFrance spent $1.5 billion on a nine-year clean up the Seine which had been closed to swimmers for 100 years because of the flow of industrial waste and sewage into the river.\n\nParis mayor Anne Hidalgo in particular was champion of the Seine clean up. Hidalgo was supposed to swim in the Seine on June 23 as a sign of confidence in the cleanliness of the river only to have the event scrapped because of high bacteria levels. A June 30 swim was postponed again, this time because of France's snap election.\n\nHidalgo finally got to take the plunge on July 17, pronouncing the Seine \"exquisite.\"\n\n\"The water is very, very good,\" the mayor said. \"A little cool, but not so bad.''\n\nBut local and IOC and international sports officials remain concerned that heavy rains could once again raise bacteria in the river to unsafe levels jeopardizing the marathon swimming and triathlon competitions. Sure enough, Paris received a downpour during last Friday's opening ceremony.\n\n\"Unfortunately, meteorological events beyond our control, such as the rain which fell over Paris on 26 and 27 July, can alter water quality and compel us to reschedule the event for health reasons. Despite the improvement of water quality levels over the last hours, the readings at some points of the swim course are still above the acceptable limits,\" Paris officials said in the communication.Officials had earlier canceled practice swims for the triathletes on Sunday and Monday.Water samples are taken 21 1/2 hours before race decisions have to be made, according to Merle, raising further concerns about the race day water conditions.\n\nAthletes and their coaches were informed of Tuesday's postponement just as they were waking up.\n\n\"The athletes got up a bit before 4 am, they were having breakfast when we received the information from the international federation,\" Bernard Maze, the France Triathlon Federation's technical director, told FranceInfo radio. \"Obviously, there's a bit of anger and a lot of disappointment.\"\n\nThe men's race was moved to 10:45 a.m. (local time), shortly after the completion of the women's race which is scheduled to start at 8 a.m.\n\n\"Both triathlons are subject to the forthcoming water tests complying with the established World Triathlon thresholds for swimming,\" Paris 2024 officials said.\n\nBut both races were threatened by forecasts of thunder storms for the Paris area later Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "dailybreeze.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Breeze"}, "authors": [{"uri": "scott_m_reid@dailybreeze.com", "name": "Scott M. passes water quality tests | Ariana News", "body": "The decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes, Reuters reported.\n\nOrganisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains, Reuters reported.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side, read the report.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes, Reuters reported.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. {"uri": "8251734056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:34:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:34:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:33:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.sabcnews.com/sabcnews/triathlon-races-to-go-ahead-as-seine-passes-water-quality-tests/", "title": "Triathlon-Races to go ahead as Seine passes water quality tests - SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all South African current events. Africa's news leader.", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Triathlon - Men's Individual - Alexander III Bridge, Paris, France - July 30, 2024. General view of the Eiffel Tower...\n\nOrganisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 am (GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 am, immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent $1.52 billion of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E.coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 am combined with a discussion between experts on overnight weather, according to Paris 2024.", "source": {"uri": "sabcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport {"uri": "2024-07-439203818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:09:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:09:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:05:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/31/sport/triathlon-seine-water-green-light-spt/index.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon goes ahead after officials give the green light over Seine water quality", "body": "Italy's Verena Steinhauser rides past a fallen athlete during the women's individual triathlon on July 31.\n\nThe triathlon competitions are up and running in Paris on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier.\n\nMore rain came into Paris overnight but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe women's race had been marked by bike crashes on the wet streets of Paris. In the cycling portion of the race, several athletes fell after slipping on the slippery roads. Vittoria Lopes of Brazil was among the leaders when she fell but fell out of contention.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand eventually was crowned women's triathlon Olympic champion on home soil, roared across the finish line by a boisterous French crowd that broke out into a rendition 'La Marseillaise.'\n\nThe men's race is set to begin at 4:45 a.m. ET.\n\nRains impacting water quality\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris over the weekend, drenching Friday's opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for a second straight day on Monday after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that Tuesday's race would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) has been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nVideo Ad Feedback\n\nCNN reporter goes swimming in the Seine after $1.5B cleanup. See how it went\n\n01:23 - Source: CNN\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races begin with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nA mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, The postponement came following assurances that the Seine River would be safe for participants.\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, executive director of sports for Paris 2024, told reporters that the decision to postpone on Tuesday was made after conducting four river tests and finding that three of the tests indicated unsafe pollution levels. She suggested that rain from July 26 and 27 caused poor water quality in the Seine.\n\nEven with storms in the Paris area late Tuesday, bacteria levels in the Seine dropped to acceptable levels Wednesday morning.\n\nRELATED STORY | U.S. women's gymnastics team soars to Olympic gold in Paris\n\nWednesday morning, French star Cassandre Beaugrand claimed the gold medal in the women's triathlon event. Beaugrand won with a total time of one hour, 54 minutes and 55 seconds. She spent 22 minutes and 32 seconds in the water.\n\nThe men's triathlon competition got underway soon after the women's event ended. Great Britain's Alex Yee earned gold in the men's event. Yee's final time was 1 hour, 43 minutes and 33 seconds. He spent 20 minutes and 37 seconds swimming the Seine.\n\nSwimming in Paris' most famed waterway has been banned for over 100 years due to pollution from factory wastewater, sewage, and rain runoff.\n\nHowever, the government has spent nearly $1.5 billion to prepare the Seine for the Olympics by fixing old pipes, limiting the amount of untreated wastewater going into the river, and building a wastewater and rainwater storage basin.\n\nThe triathlon involves a 1,500-meter swim, a 40-kilometer cycle and a 10-kilometer run. The Seine is also expected to be the site of next week's marathon swimming event, which involves a 10-kilometer swim. There is also a mixed triathlon event scheduled for next week.\n\nInternational Olympic Committee spokesperson Anne Descamps told reporters on Wednesday that she was \"pleased\" Wednesday's events could commence, and that the IOC would be focused on making sure the river is ready for next week's marathon swimming and mixed triathlon events.", "source": {"uri": "koaa.com", "dataType": "news", tests show river safe - UPI.com", "body": "\"We will swim,\" World Triathlon said Wednesday morning in a post on X.\n\nThe announcement comes after water analyses received at 3:20 a.m. local time Wednesday showed levels compliant with World Triathlon standards, the sport's governing body and Paris Olympics organizers said in a statement.\n\nThe men's triathlon was originally scheduled for 8 a.m. Tuesday but was postponed following failed water quality tests of the Seine River where athletes are to compete in the swim portion of the three-leg race.\n\nConcerns over whether the triathlons would take place had long been stoked heading into the Olympics as swimming in the Seine has been banned for a century.\n\nOver the course of nearly a decade, some $1.5 billion has been spent to improve the environmental and sanitary quality of the water in the Seine to make it swimmable in the long term and, on the short term, an Olympic venue this week.\n\nAs recently as last month, a report was published showing the river was still too unsafe for swimming.\n\nBut efforts continued, and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip in the river two weeks ago to show it was on track for good showing at the Olympics.\n\nHowever, heavy rains on Friday and Saturday resulted in a drop in the river's water quality, forcing organizers to postpone the men's race on Tuesday.\n\nFriday was slated as a contingency date.\n\nThe triathlon is not the only event using the Seine for Olympic competition.\n\nThe women's 10-km marathon swimming event is scheduled to take place 7:30 a.m. on Aug. 8, with Reuters\n\nTriathlon events will finally take place in the Seine River, the organisers confirmed on Wednesday after the latest water tests showed lower levels of bacteria. The men's triathlon was to take place on Tuesday but was postponed to Wednesday after the Seine River failed quality tests.\n\nThe races will take place on Wednesday. This has come as a big relief for the organisers and the athletes but it will also be a big test for Paris authorities who have promised residents the swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nOlympics 2024: India Day 5 schedule\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. {"uri": "8251615372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:30:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:30:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:30:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/sport/olympics/seine-river-gets-go-ahead-for-olympic-triathlon-races-c-15538676", "title": "Seine river gets go-ahead for Olympic triathlon races", "body": "Seine river gets go-ahead for Olympic triathlon racesStaff WritersAPWed, 31 July 2024 10:28AM\n\nAfter days of delays and uncertainty over water quality in the Seine River, the women's and men's Olympic triathlon races will go ahead on Wednesday.\n\nParis Games organisers said early Wednesday latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards, allowing the swim legs to be held in the river.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river had pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition is also scheduled.\n\nTest events meant to allow the athletes to familiarise themselves with the course had already been cancelled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe decision to proceed with the Seine swim legs for the triathlon competitions is a big win for the city, Olympics organisers and the athletes.\n\nOfficials undertook an ambitious plan, including 1.4 billion euros ($A2.3 billion) infrastructure improvements, to clean up the long-polluted Seine and have been steadfast in their insistence that the swimming portion of the triathlon and the marathon swimming events next week could safely be held in the river.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine is directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river.\n\nHeavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nmedal tallyGame On ParisLoading...Full Medal TallyOlympics CoverageGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The West Australian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon", "type": {"uri": "8251263539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:57:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:57:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:56:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/how-1-5b-plan-to-clean-seine-and-save-paris-14th-century-sewers-failed/", "title": "How $1.5B Plan to Clean Seine and Save Paris' 14th-Century Sewers Failed", "body": "A $1.5 billion initiative to revitalize Paris' ancient sewer system and make the Seine river swimmable for the 2024 Summer Olympics has all but collapsed, raising doubts about the river's readiness for swimming competitions.\n\nConcerns about the river's cleanliness led to the postponement of the men's triathlon on Tuesday. Officials hope the swimming portion of the event can soon proceed following the expensive cleanup effort.\n\nOrganizers plan to hold the men's triathlon on Wednesday instead. The women's competition is also scheduled for the same day, but both events will only happen if water tests show acceptable levels of E. coli and other bacteria. Friday is the backup date.\n\nHeavy rain and thunderstorms are in the forecast from Tuesday night through Thursday, which could complicate the rescheduling. Rain, like the downpour that dampened Friday's Opening Ceremony, generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" American triathlete Seth Rider told the Associated Press. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon, and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nSwimming has been off-limits in the long-polluted Seine for more than a century. In preparation for the Games, the city promised to clean its famed river to demonstrate that hosting the Olympics would provide benefits to skeptical Parisians.\n\nThe city invested millions in building a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and prevent untreated waste from flowing into the Seine, renovating the sewage system, and upgrading water treatment plants.\n\nParis Mayor Anne Hidalgo has been a vocal advocate for the cleanup, even taking a symbolic swim in the Seine to demonstrate her confidence in the project's success.\n\n\"Our objective is an Olympic legacy,\" said Pierre Rabadan, the deputy mayor overseeing the project. \"That you and I or whoever happens to be in Paris can swim in the Seine.\"\n\nDespite those best efforts, Mother Nature intervened at the worst possible time, delivering torrential rain to central Paris all day on Friday, before and during the Opening ceremony and persisting into Saturday. Training events meant to let the triathletes familiarize themselves with the course were canceled on both Sunday and Monday due to water quality concerns.\n\nOrganizers had expressed confidence in recent days that bacteria levels would improve as skies cleared and temperatures warmed this week, but that was not sufficient to ensure the athletes' safety on Tuesday.\n\n\"Despite the improvement in water quality levels in the last hours, the readings at some points of the swim course are still above the acceptable limits,\" organizers said, stressing that their \"priority is the health of the athletes.\"\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming after continued delays, that part of the race would be scrapped and only the cycling and running portions would go forward. Something similar happened last year at the European Championships in Madrid, when the triathlon format was switched due to water quality issues in the Casa de Campo lake.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure E. coli levels, which indicate sewage contamination. While most E. coli strains are harmless and live in the intestines of healthy people and animals, some can be dangerous. Swallowing contaminated water can cause diarrhea and illnesses like urinary tract or intestinal infections.\n\nWorld Triathlon, the international governing body for the multi-discipline sport, has water safety guidelines that, along with a 2006 European Union directive, set the safe limit for E. coli at 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters. On Tuesday, one of the four test sites was below this threshold. However, two sites were just above the limit, and one site had much higher levels, ranging from 980 to 1,553.\n\nSome experts and residents remain skeptical. A recent poll by the French market-research firm Ifop found that 70% of respondents viewed the Seine negatively, describing it as dirty, polluted and smelly.\n\nDo you have a story Newsweek should be covering? Do you have any questions about this story? Contact [email protected]\n\nNewsweek is committed to challenging conventional wisdom and finding connections in the search for common ground.\n\nNewsweek is committed to challenging conventional wisdom and finding connections in the search for common ground.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_(sport)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Swimming (sport)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8251122749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:56:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/heres-what-to-know-about-whats-next-for-olympic-triathlon-in-wake-of-seine-river-water-quality/600387659/", "title": "Here's what to know about what's next for Olympic triathlon in wake of Seine River water quality", "body": "PARIS -- The biggest opponent to the swim portion of the triathlon held in the Seine River: E. coli.\n\nBacteria levels in the famed waterway have left organizers of the Paris Games scrambling toward backup plans and even tweaks to the competition in order to make sure they can stage the races. The risky levels of E. coli have already led to swim training to be canceled and on Tuesday the men's competition being pushed back.\n\nOfficials remain hopeful the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted river Wednesday -- or in the coming days. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only happen if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river.\n\nAnother potential hiccup: A forecast of rain beginning Tuesday night and running through Thursday could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nIf the river isn't safe for swimming, that portion of the race could potentially be scrapped and only the cycling and running parts would be staged to determine the medal winners.\n\nHow big is swimming in the triathlon competition?\n\nThere are three triathlon races that will be held at the Paris Games -- the men's and women's competitions, along with a mixed relay. In the triathlon world, the order of events is swimming, biking and running primarily out of safety concerns. The Olympic triathlon distance for the men and women is slightly less than a mile (1.5 kilometers) for the swim, 25 miles (40 kilometers) for cycling and then a 6.2-mile (10K) run.\n\nIt's been part of the Olympic program since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\n''Pretty crazy to be here after dreaming of it for so long,'' said 27-year-old U.S. triathlete Seth Rider, who took up the sport when he was 6 years old.\n\nWhat can the athletes do during the delays?\n\nLike everyone, triathletes are just waiting on the water-quality reports to come back favorable. In the meantime, they still need to train.\n\nThere are plenty of places to run, of course, even through the busy side streets around the Arrondissements of Paris. High-speed cycling has places, too. But to train for an open-water swim, one option could be the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region.\n\nOr, possibly even a hotel pool. But of course that would mean lots and lots and lots of laps to get in the work they need.\n\nCould the swimming location change?\n\nThe women's and men's marathon swimming events are set for Aug. 8 and Aug. 9. For those competitions, backup plans could include relocating, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium. It already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nThat said, it's not easy to just pick up and move the triathlon. One part is predicated on another.\n\nAfter the swim, racers go through a transition area to get to their bikes. After cycling, another transition to prepare for the run. The routes are already set up for cycling and running.\n\nIf no swimming leg, then what?\n\nShould the river not clear up, the swimming part could always be nixed and the race feature only cycling and running. That was the case last year at the European Championships when the format was switched to a ''duathlon'' because of water-quality issues.\n\nAsked if that might be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water, World Triathlon president Marisol Casado responded: ''It's just another situation of the competition.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": The men's race, which was originally scheduled for Tuesday, will now happen on Wednesday at 10:45 just after the women's at 08:00.\n\nThe swimming portion of the triathlon is set to take place in the river that flows through the heart of the French capital, part of a plan by organizers to make the Seine itself a star attraction during the Games. The mixed relay triathlon event is scheduled for 5 August along the river, with the women's and men's 10-kilometer distance swim races set for 8 and 9 August.\n\nTo make it safe for swimmers, authorities spent \u20ac1.4 billion on new infrastructure to clean up the river, as a streak of rainy days can cause the sewage system to overflow, bringing waste water and bacteria into the Seine. The opening ceremony was hit by heavy rain on Friday that persisted well into Saturday evening, prompting the cancellation of the rehearsals of two water portions of the swim-bike-run race.\n\nRain "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/triathlon-goes-ahead-river-seine-passes-pollution-tests-paris-olympics-2024/", "title": "Billion-euro Olympic triathlon event goes ahead as River Seine passes pollution tests", "body": "PARIS, France - Organizers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday, July 31, after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday, July 30, but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 am, with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 am, immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3:20 am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimize spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganizers make the call based on analysis of river samples Olympics: Triathlon races to go ahead on Wednesday as Seine passes water quality tests", "body": "Organisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe decision came as a relief for the athletes expecting to compete and for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nLatest on SportstarParis Olympics 2024: US men fall to Serbia 22-14 in 3x3 men's basketball in disappointing debut; {"uri": "8252052968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:33:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:33:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:32:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/olympic-triathlon-goes-ahead-after-officials-give-the-green-light-over-seine-water-quality/article_bdc93198-6b1c-506b-ba2a-dab93b24b507.html", "title": "Olympic triathlon goes ahead after officials give the green light over Seine water quality", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- The triathlon competitions are up and running in Paris on Wednesday after concerns over water quality in the River Seine caused the men's race to be postponed a day earlier.\n\nMore rain came into Paris overnight but World Triathlon and Paris 2024 determined the water quality was sufficient to move ahead for both the women's and men's races.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3:30 a.m. attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. respectively,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a joint statement.\n\nThe women's race had been marked by bike crashes on the wet streets of Paris. In the cycling portion of the race, several athletes fell after slipping on the slippery roads. Vittoria Lopes of Brazil was among the leaders when she fell but fell out of contention.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand eventually was crowned women's triathlon Olympic champion on home soil, roared across the finish line by a boisterous French crowd that broke out into a rendition 'La Marseillaise.'\n\nThe men's race is set to begin at 4:45 a.m. ET.\n\nRains impacting water quality\n\nHeavy rains battered Paris over the weekend, drenching Friday's opening ceremony and raising concerns about water quality in the river, which usually declines after rainfall.\n\nTraining was canceled for a second straight day on Monday after water quality testing deemed the water unsafe for athletes, but organizers were confident at the time that Tuesday's race would go ahead as planned.\n\nThe decision to hold some swimming events in the famous river that splits Paris raised eyebrows when it was first announced. Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century but, in their desire to put the host city on full display, organizers worked up a plan to clean up the river so the world's best athletes could use it during Paris 2024.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) has been spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games and Paris officials have made a big show of displaying its suitability. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier this month to display her confidence in the river's water quality and promised to put a swimming pool in the river after the Games. The French sports minister has also gone for a dip in the Seine.\n\nOne of the key infrastructure projects designed to help tackle pollution has been a new rainwater storage basin - called the Austerlitz basin - which can hold 20 Olympic swimming pools worth of water, according to a statement from Paris 2024.\n\nFollowing rainy weather on June 17 and 18, the basin filled to 80% capacity, successfully preventing 40,000 cubic meters (40 million liters) of wastewater and rainwater from being discharged into the Seine, according to the city of Paris.\n\nBut the water quality can change fast. Official data shows one-off rainfall events can quickly cause E. coli levels to spike again, and as recently as June 30 - following rain the previous day - E. coli levels increased to around 2000 CFU/100mL at Alexandra III Bridge, where the race is set to begin.\n\nThat's double the level needed for \"good\" water quality, as per World Triathlon standards.\n\nFor much of the month before the games, E. coli levels were above acceptable levels, which could expose athletes to serious health concerns. If E. Coli levels are above 1000 CFU/100mL, the swimming leg of the triathlon will have to be cancelled, according to World Triathlon competition rules, unless the organization's medical committee decides the race can go ahead.\n\nThe individual triathlon races begin with a 1.5-kilometer swim, followed by a 40K bike race - passing by the Le Grand Palais and the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es - before finishing with a 10K run through the heart of the city.\n\nA mixed team relay race involving four athletes - two men and two women - will start with each team member completing a 300-meter swim, followed by a 5.8K bike ride and 1.8K run.\n\nCNN's Homero De La Fuente, Kevin Dotson and Chris Liakos contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8252136908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:25:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:25:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:24:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/07/31/sports/2024-paris-olympics-france-cassandre-beaugrand-wins-womens-triathlon-after-seine-river-given-green-light/", "title": "France's Beaugrand wins gold after Seine passes water quality tests", "body": "France's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's triathlon at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday, cheered on by a delighted crowd as the hosts' gamble to hold the swim stage of the race in the Seine paid off after days of uncertainty.\n\nThe triathlon, a central showpiece of the Paris Games, started and finished at the Alexandre III bridge at the heart of the French capital, taking athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past more Parisian landmarks including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but, after the river failed water quality tests, it was postponed to 10:45 a.m. on Wednesday, immediately after the women's race.\n\nThe women began their competition at 8 a.m., just as overnight rain was easing, the triathlon offering spectacular views as they swam in the Seine before racing their bikes and running into central Paris.\n\nA handful of athletes crashed off their bicycles after slipping on the wet cobblestones of the Champs-Elysees.\n\nWorld number one Beaugrand broke away on the last lap of the run stage and was fueled to the finish line by ecstatic cheers from crowds lining the streets.\n\nSwitzerland's Julie Derron won silver and Britain's Beth Potter took bronze.\n\nThe races going ahead will have come as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganizers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with Beaugrand and Potter diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.52 billion of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimize spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251674743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:39:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:39:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:38:58Z", "dataType": "news", Seine passes water quality tests", "body": "Organisers have cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria.\n\nIt ends days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe decision came as a relief for the athletes expecting to compete and for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 6pm NZ time, with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 8.45pm NZ time, immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters.\n\n\"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nParis has spent US$2.4 billion of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.", "source": {"uri": "8251988121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:51:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:51:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:50:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/lifestyle/health/seine-unsafe-for-olympic-triathlon-swimmers-risks-of-swimming-in-polluted-water-101722411417368.html", "title": "Seine unsafe for Olympic triathlon swimmers: Risks of swimming in polluted water", "body": "Olympic swimming events in Paris' Seine river have been postponed due to health concerns. What are the risks of swimming in polluted water?\n\nThe men's Olympic triathlon planned for Tuesday has been postponed over concerns about water quality in Paris' Seine river, where the swimming portion of the race was supposed to take place.\n\nThe event has been postponed to Wednesday, which is the same day the women's competition is also scheduled to take place. However, both events are subject to water tests desmonstrating that the Seine is safe to swim in.\n\nQuestions also remain about the women's and men's 10-kilometer (6.21-mile) marathon swimming races, which are due to be held in the Seine on August 8 and 9.\n\nALSO READ: Olympic women triathletes begin swim in Seine River after days of concerns about water quality\n\nWater contamination in the Seine has been a controversial topic in recent weeks. A triathlon training session due to be held in the Seine was cancelled on Monday, which is the latest event to be scuttled by water pollution.\n\nPollution in the Seine is no new controversy -- swimming in the river has been illegal for more than 100 years due to health concerns. The first ban came into effect in 1923, causing swimmers during the 1924 Paris Olympic games to compete in swimming pools.\n\nMost of the city's wastewater has been flowing into the Seine since the ban came into effect. Leaking and overflowing sewage systems are the main source of pollution.\n\nFrench authorities have been working to clean up the water for the 2024 Paris Olympic Games, spending \u20ac1.4 billion ($1.5 billion) on improving water quality.\n\nThe goal was to cut bacterial contamination by 75% before the first Olympic swimming event, but the city has so far been unsuccessful in quelling the concerns of athletes and local Parisians.\n\nParisians disgruntled at the project's costs pledged to protest poo in the Seine en masse, led by #JeChieDansLaSeineLe23Juin, which tranlastes as # I shit in the Seine on June 23.\n\nDespite this campaign, Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the river earlier in July in a bid to demonstrate the Seine's cleanliness first-hand.\n\nALSO READ: Paris Olympics 2024: Men's triathlon race postponed to Wednesday due to Seine pollution levels\n\nWater tests from the Eau de Paris monitoring group showed levels of Escherichia coli (E. coli) in the river were significantly higher than is safe to humans over the last weeks.\n\nRecent rainfall over Paris has made the issue worse -- heavy rains often cause levels of E. coli and other bacterial colonies in rivers and lakesto rise.\n\nIn a statement, organizers said that the heavy rain over Paris on Friday and Saturday had compelled them to \"reschedule the event for health reasons.\"\n\nE. coli is often linked to fecal matter in water and can indicate contamination from sewage. Even a mouthful of contaminated water containing high levels of E.coli can lead to diarrhea, urinary tract infections, pneumonia or sepsis. Skin rashes and ear or eye pain are also common.\n\nE. coli infections are not the only concern, however. Leptospira, transmitted by rodent urine, can be found in contaminated water and can cause severe kidney disease.\n\nInfections from other waterborne bacteria like cyanobacteria and enterococci can also cause gut-related health problems.\n\nAnd then there are parasites like cercarial larvae, often found in water populated by waterfowl, which can cause itchy skin rashes.\n\nSeth Rider, one of 55 triathletes entered in the men's race, has been taking unconventional measures to prepare for exposure to bacteria.\n\n\"We know that there's going to be some E. coli exposure, so I just try to increase my E. coli threshold by exposing myself to a bit of E. coli in your day-to-day life,\" the US athlete said in a press conference on Saturday.\n\nALSO READ: Cholera, dysentery and more in rainy season: Tips to protect vulnerable family members from monsoon waterborne diseases\n\n\"Just little things throughout your day, like, not washing your hands after you go to the bathroom and stuff like this,\" he said.\n\nOther Olympic athletes have suffered long-term from swimming in contaminated waters, however. Emma Frodeno (n\u00e9e Snowsill), an Australian triathlon athlete, retired in 2014 after struggling with health problems related to swimming in polluted water at a World Cup event.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251609086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:22:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:22:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:21:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/sports/olympics/triathletes-will-swim-seine-last-minute-testing-shows-river-safe-rcna164401", "title": "Triathletes will swim in Seine as last-minute testing shows the river is safe", "body": "A couple walks in the heat next to the infrastructure to be used for the triathlon on the banks of the Seine, following the cancellation of the first triathlon event of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games on Tuesday.Thibaud Moritz / AFP - Getty Images\n\nAfter months of speculation about whether the River Seine would be clean enough for Olympic athletes to compete in it, officials deemed the water safe for swimming following a last-minute test.\n\nThe favorable test of the river's water quality on Wednesday morning Paris time means the men and women will swim in back-to-back races as part of the triathlon event, beginning at 8 a.m. local time. The men's race had originally been scheduled for Tuesday but got postponed after the Seine failed water quality tests.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3:20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" said a news release from Paris organizers and World Triathlon, the sport's governing body.\n\nWater quality on the Seine became something of a saga leading up to the Games, as organizers raced to prepare the polluted waterway for prime-time attention. For months, the French have been testing river samples for E. Coli and enterococci bacteria, which are indicators of fecal matter, as well as other pathogens. When E.Coli levels are high, swimmers risk developing gastrointestinal illness.\n\nThe Seine had been failing those tests after rainy weather, since storms can send runoff, and sometimes sewage, into the river.\n\nSwimming had been disallowed on the Seine for more than a century because it was too polluted, but the city of Paris led a $1.5 billion effort to clean up the river and shore up waste treatment systems in the lead-up to the Olympics.\n\nAs the first events approached, organizers had hoped for clear, sunny weather to reduce overall pollution and allow ultraviolet light to inactivate some bacteria.\n\nBut the weather has rarely cooperated.\n\nLast year, some test events to rehearse the triathlon had to be canceled because of water quality concerns after rainfall.\n\nThen the opening ceremony, which involved a boat parade on the Seine, took place amid some downpours on Friday, and the showers lasted into Saturday.\n\nThat rainfall caused pollution and forced organizers to cancel two days of swim training on Sunday and Monday. Then they postponed the men's triathlon, which was originally slated for Tuesday morning.\n\n\"I'm just trying to focus on what I can control,\" Kirsten Kasper, an American triathlete, told NBC News on Tuesday. \"We swim in a lot of city locations, and it's common for water quality to be a question. But I just have to trust that the race organizers are doing the testing and what they need to do to make sure it's safe.\"\n\nWater quality experts said the difficulties in ensuring that the Seine was sufficiently clean could draw needed attention to broader issues of environmental contamination, which are common worldwide.\n\n\"It's just very hard to manage, in large cities, the amount of human waste that we see,\" said Katy Graham, an assistant professor at Georgia Tech's College of Engineering. \"The public thinks a lot of these issues have been completely solved. {"uri": "8251198286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:00:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:00:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:00:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.oann.com/newsroom/olympic-triathlon-swimming-in-jeopardy-due-to-high-levels-of-contamination-in-seine-river/", "title": "Olympic Triathlon Swimming 'In Jeopardy' Due To High Levels Of Contamination In Seine River", "body": "The discovery of high levels of fecal bacteria and E. coli in Paris' Seine River led to the postponement of the men's Olympic triathlon.\n\nThe event was initially scheduled to take place on Tuesday morning, but it is now expected to take place on Wednesday, as long as the tests show \"acceptable levels\" of contamination.\n\nThe World Triathlon organization released a statement on X (Twitter) explaining the situation.\n\n\"Unfortunately, meteorological events beyond our control, such as the rain, which fell over Paris on 26 and 27 July, can alter water quality and compel us to reschedule the event for health reasons,\" the organization stated.\n\nThe question of whether or not Paris' river would be clean enough for Olympic swimmers to safely compete has been tightly monitored by event organizers and city officials.\n\nSwimming in the Seine river has been banned since 1923 and has cost $1.5 billion in an effort to make the river swimmable. These efforts have included constructing a massive basin to hold large amounts of rainwater to keep wastewater from diverging into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure, and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.\n\nHowever, even with the pricey renovations, heavy rainfall on the 26 and 27 of July led to water tests surpassing the acceptable levels of E. coli.\n\nPrior to the announcement of the delay, event organizers had expressed confidence in the power of the clear skies and hot temperatures to bring bacteria levels under acceptable rates, yet it turned out not to be the case.\n\nA contingency plan is now in place for August 2.\n\n\"It's disappointing that there's this negative aspect now with the delay,\" said U.S. triathlete Seth Rider. \"But I hope we can have a triathlon and I can accomplish this dream that I've had since I was a little kid.\"\n\nIf conditions do not improve in the Seine River, the swimming portion of the competition would be canceled altogether, leaving {"uri": "8251635618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:57:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:57:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:56:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/triathletes-will-swim-in-seine-as-last-minute-testing-shows-the-river-is-safe/", "title": "Triathletes will swim in Seine as last-minute testing shows the river is safe", "body": "After months of speculation about whether the River Seine would be clean enough for Olympic athletes to compete in it, officials deemed the water safe for swimming following a last-minute test.\n\nThe favorable test of the river's water quality on Wednesday morning Paris time means the men and women will swim in back-to-back races as part of the triathlon event, beginning at 8 a.m. local time. The men's race had originally been scheduled for Tuesday but got postponed after the Seine failed water quality tests.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3:20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" said a news release from Paris organizers and World Triathlon, the sport's governing body.\n\nWater quality on the Seine became something of a saga leading up to the Games, as organizers raced to prepare the polluted waterway for prime-time attention. For months, the French have been testing river samples for E. Coli and enterococci bacteria, which are indicators of fecal matter, as well as other pathogens. When E.Coli levels are high, swimmers risk developing gastrointestinal illness.\n\nThe Seine had been failing those tests after rainy weather, since storms can send runoff, and sometimes sewage, into the river.\n\nSwimming had been disallowed on the Seine for more than a century because it was too polluted, but the city of Paris led a $1.5 billion effort to clean up the river and shore up waste treatment systems in the lead-up to the Olympics.\n\nAs the first events approached, organizers had hoped for clear, sunny weather to reduce overall pollution and allow ultraviolet light to inactivate some bacteria.\n\nBut the weather has rarely cooperated.\n\nLast year, some test events to rehearse the triathlon had to be canceled because of water quality concerns after rainfall.\n\nThen the opening ceremony, which involved a boat parade on the Seine, took place amid some downpours on Friday, and the showers lasted into Saturday.\n\nThat rainfall caused pollution and forced organizers to cancel two days of swim training on Sunday and Monday. Then they postponed the men's triathlon, which was originally slated for Tuesday morning.\n\n\"I'm just trying to focus on what I can control,\" Kirsten Kasper, an American triathlete, told NBC News on Tuesday. \"We swim in a lot of city locations, and it's common for water quality to be a question. But I just have to trust that the race organizers are doing the testing and what they need to do to make sure it's safe.\"\n\nWater quality experts said the difficulties in ensuring that the Seine was sufficiently clean could draw needed attention to broader issues of environmental contamination, which are common worldwide.\n\n\"It's just very hard to manage, in large cities, the amount of human waste that we see,\" said Katy Graham, an assistant professor at Georgia Tech's College of Engineering. \"The public thinks a lot of these issues have been completely solved. They're most certainly not.\"", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_quality", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "8251649001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:12:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:12:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:11:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/30/sports/olympic-triathletes-will-swim-paris-seine-river-after-days-concerns-about-water-quality/", "title": "Olympic triathletes will swim in Paris' Seine River after days of concerns about water quality - The Boston Globe", "body": "The organizers said early Wednesday the latest tests of the water showed compliance with quality standards.\n\nElevated levels of bacteria in the river pushed the men's race originally planned for Tuesday to Wednesday, when the women's competition had been scheduled. Test events meant to allow the athletes to familiarize themselves with the course had already been canceled for the same reason on Sunday and Monday.\n\nThe water quality in the Seine directly affected by rainfall that can lead to wastewater runoff flowing into the river. Heavy rains fell during Friday's Olympic opening ceremony, and rain continued for most of the day Saturday.\n\nEvery day since Sunday, even as organizers announced cancellations or postponements, they continued to express confidence that the swims in the Seine would go forward as planned the next day. For several days they did not publicly release the data on levels of E. coli and other bacteria that contributed to their decisions.\n\nHigh levels of E. coli in water can indicate contamination from sewage. Most strains are harmless and some live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. But others can be dangerous. Even a mouthful of contaminated water can lead to diarrhea, and the germ can cause illnesses such as infections in the urinary tract or in the intestines.\n\nDaily water quality tests measure levels of the fecal bacteria E. coli. World Triathlon's water safety guidelines and a 2006 European Union directive give a range of E. coli levels from \"excellent\" to \"sufficient.\" Anything beyond 900 colony-forming units per 100 milliliters is not considered safe or \"sufficient.\" But experts stressed that these numbers are simply guidelines used to assess risk.\n\nPlus, Aur\u00e9lie Merle, the Paris 2024 director of sports, told reporters Tuesday that water samples are taken 21 and a half hours before decisions are made about the swim. That leaves uncertainty about their accuracy the day of the race.\n\nMerle said Tuesday that testing results showed \"we're very close to the threshold of triathlon.\" She noted that one of four test sites along the triathlon course was below the threshold for E. coli. Two other sites were just above the limit and one was more elevated, she said, citing a range of 980 to 1,553.\n\n\"We know the sun and the heat have a very strong impact on the quality of the water,\" she said, hoping that a heat wave that hit most of France on Tuesday would help improve water quality enough for the swims to go ahead.\n\nOrganizers have said the marathon swimming races, scheduled for Aug. 8 and 9, could be relocated, if needed, to the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region, which already hosts rowing and canoeing competitions and can accommodate up to 15,000 spectators.\n\nEfforts to make the river suitable for swimming included the construction of a giant basin to capture excess rainwater and keep wastewater from flowing into the river, renovating sewer infrastructure and upgrading wastewater treatment plants.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Swimming in the Seine has been illegal for a century.\n\nAbout $1.5 billion (1.4 billion Euros) was spent trying to clean up the river ahead of the Games. {"uri": "8252175590", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:49:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:49:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:48:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/f0d01e03-c5fb-4497-8857-006565dc0cd6", "title": "Paris Olympic triathletes swim in Seine after bacteria levels subside", "body": "Women triathletes dove off a blue pontoon into the Seine river on Wednesday morning after the water finally tested as safe for competition, following days of delays and fierce criticism of Paris Olympics organisers.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" said the organisers and World Triathlon.\n\nThe announcement came after two practice sessions were cancelled and the men's triathlon was postponed by 24 hours to Wednesday because of high levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the water.\n\nThe French government had insisted on holding the swimming leg of triathlon races in the Seine, in an effort to revive bathing in the Parisian river after a century-long ban. Authorities spent \u20ac1.4bn on a years-long infrastructure push to make the Seine clean enough for the competition, but the plan remains entirely weather dependent.\n\nWhen it rains heavily, as it did on Friday and Saturday, the city's antique sewers overflow into the river so as to avoid flooding the streets with sewage. Paris sought to mitigate that risk by building a massive underground storage tank that could capture up to 46,000 cubic metres of wastewater to avoid it going into the river after storms.\n\nBut the system was overwhelmed by the bad weather last week, putting at risk organisers' often repeated promises that the river would be ready for the triathlon and marathon swimming. For several days tests showed E. coli and other bacteria levels were higher than the level of 900 colony-forming units limit set by World Triathlon as safe for competitions.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron celebrated the long-awaited moment with a reminder of the state's financial commitment. \"Here we are! The Seine is swimmable,\" he said on social media on Wednesday.\n\nThe triathlon was supposed to be a highlight of the Paris Olympics given that the course was set against the dramatic backdrop of the Seine and well-known monuments -- the swimming starting at the Pont Alexandre III bridge, followed by cycling and running along the Champs \u00c9lys\u00e9es and past the Mus\u00e9e d'Orsay.\n\nInstead, it began a flashpoint for criticism that the organisers had put their desire for postcard perfect event backdrops ahead of the needs of athletes who train for years to be able to compete in the Olympics. There was no back-up site for the triathlon to be held if the river was too dirty to swim, although one was set for marathon swimming, the other event to be held in the Seine.\n\nWith more summer storms forecast in the coming days, it remains unclear if the mixed triathlon relay and marathon swimming can be held next week.\n\nOn Wednesday, tens of thousands of fans were lined up along the Seine and the Champs \u00c9lys\u00e9es to cheer on the triathletes.\n\nFrench athlete Cassandre Beaugrand broke through the finish line first to win the country's first gold medal in the event. Switzerland's Julie Derron won silver, and Team GB's Beth Potter won bronze.", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Financial Times News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251655831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:18:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:18:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:18:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/olympics-triathlon-races-to-go-ahead-on-wednesday-as-seine-passes-water-quality-tests/85528591", "title": "Olympics-Triathlon-Races to go ahead on Wednesday as Seine passes water quality tests", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) -Organisers cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead on Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but was postponed until Wednesday after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead on Wednesday came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight and forecasts for showers around midday which could hit towards the end of the men's event.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. combined with a discussion between experts on overnight weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\n($1 = 0.9240 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Helen Reid; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "swi_swissinfo_ch@swissinfo.ch", "name": "Swi {"uri": "8252196803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:02:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:02:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/beaugrand-claims-triathlon-gold-as-seine-passes-test-paris-olympics/20240731.htm", "title": "Beaugrand claims triathlon gold as Seine passes test", "body": "IMAGE: Cassandre Beaugrand of France reacts after crossing the line to win the gold medal. Photograph: Aleksandra Szmigiel/Reuters\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's triathlon at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday, cheered on by a delighted crowd as the hosts' gamble to hold the swim stage of the race in the Seine paid off after days of uncertainty.\n\nThe triathlon, a central showpiece of the Paris Games, started and finished at the Alexandre III bridge at the heart of the French capital, taking athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past more Parisian landmarks including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but, after the river failed water quality tests, it was postponed to 10:45 a.m. (0845 GMT) on Wednesday, immediately after the women's race.\n\nThe women began their competition at 8 a.m., just as overnight rain was easing, with the triathlon offering spectacular views as they swam in the Seine before racing their bikes and running into central Paris.\n\nA handful of athletes crashed off their bicycles after slipping on the wet cobblestones of the Champs-Elysees.\n\nWorld number one Beaugrand broke away on the last lap of the run stage and was fuelled to the finish line by ecstatic cheers from crowds lining the streets. Switzerland's Julie Derron won silver and Britain's Beth Potter took bronze.\n\nThe races going ahead will have come as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"We have achieved in four years what has been impossible for a century: the Seine is swimmable,\" President Emmanuel Macron tweeted after the race.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria such as E. coli to rise.\n\n\"I have no doubts about the quality of the Seine, we've swum in worse water,\" Beaugrand said after her victory, adding that scrapping the swim and holding a duathlon -- the organisers' last resort if the river had been too dirty -- would have been \"shameful\" for the sport.\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with Beaugrand and Potter diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water would not make them ill.\n\nTHE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com",
