{"uri": "8251706269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:09:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:09:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:08:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/heres-what-to-know-about-whats-next-for-olympic-triathlon-in-wake-of-seine-river-water-quality-5696590", "title": "Here's What to Know About What's Next for Olympic Triathlon in Wake of Seine River Water Quality", "body": "PARIS -- The biggest opponent to the swim portion of the triathlon held in the Seine River: E. coli.\n\nBacteria levels in the famed waterway have left organizers of the Paris Games scrambling toward backup plans and even tweaks to the competition in order to make sure they can stage the races. The risky levels of E. coli have already led to swim training to be canceled and on Tuesday the men's competition being pushed back.\n\nOfficials remain hopeful the swimming portion of the race will be able to go forward in the long-polluted river Wednesday -- or in the coming days. The women's competition also is scheduled for Wednesday, but both will only happen if water tests show safe levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the river.\n\nAnother potential hiccup: A forecast of rain beginning Tuesday night and running through Thursday could complicate efforts to reschedule the events. Rain generally causes bacteria levels in the Seine to rise.\n\nIt's been part of the Olympic program since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\nThere are plenty of places to run, of course, even through the busy side streets around the Arrondissements of Paris. High-speed cycling has places, too. But to train for an open-water swim, one option could be the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium in the greater Paris region.\n\nThat said, it's not easy to just pick up and move the triathlon. One part is predicated on another.\n\nAsked if that might be unfair to triathletes who excel in the water, World Triathlon president Marisol Casado responded: \"It's just another situation of the competition.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli", {"uri": "8252072518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:46:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:46:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:45:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.sabcnews.com/sabcnews/beaugrand-wins-womens-triathlon-gold-in-french-first/", "title": "Beaugrand wins women's triathlon gold in French first - SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all South African current events. Africa's news leader.", "body": "Cassandre Beaugrand of France reacts after winning the gold medal.\n\nFrance's Cassandre Beaugrand won gold in the women's triathlon at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday, cheered on by a delighted crowd as the hosts' gamble to hold the swim stage of the race in the Seine paid off after days of uncertainty.\n\nThe triathlon, a central showpiece of the Paris Games, started and finished at the Alexandre III bridge at the heart of the French capital, taking athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past more Parisian landmarks including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday but, after the river failed water quality tests, it was postponed to 10:45 a.m. (0845 GMT) on Wednesday, immediately after the women's race.\n\nThe women began their competition at 8 a.m., just as overnight rain was easing, the triathlon offering spectacular views as they swam in the Seine before racing their bikes and running into central Paris.\n\nA handful of athletes crashed off their bicycles after slipping on the wet cobblestones of the Champs-Elysees.\n\nWorld number one Beaugrand broke away on the last lap of the run stage and was fuelled to the finish line by ecstatic cheers from crowds lining the streets. Switzerland's Julie Derron won silver and Britain's Beth Potter took bronze.\n\nThe races going ahead will have come as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nGREEN LIGHT\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with Beaugrand and Potter diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.", "source": {"uri": "sabcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all Switzerland's Julie Derron won silver and Britain's Beth Potter took bronze.\n\nALSO READ:\n\nThe races going ahead will have come as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never men's and women's Olympic triathlons will be allowed take place on Wednesday after tests showed the River Seine to be clean enough for competition.\n\nIt follows concerns they could follow the same fate as Tuesday's men's event, which was postponed due to the Seine's water quality.\n\nOrganisers had previously said the events only had a 60% chance of going ahead after that was postponed.\n\nResults from the latest water analyses, received at 03:20 on Wednesday, were deemed compliant by World Triathlon.\n\nGreat Britain's Alex Yee is one of the favourites for gold in the men's race, while team-mate Beth Potter is the reigning women's world champion.\n\nThe event going ahead removes previous concerns it may have had to have been contested as a duathlon - with just swimming and cycling - as a last resort.\n\nDaily tests of the Seine's quality are carried out, with recent heavy rain causing the river to be too dirty for competition.\n\nEarlier in the games, swimming training sessions were cancelled because of the water quality, but organisers were confident the triathlon events would go ahead as scheduled.\n\nTests are being carried out daily on the water quality in the Seine, which is also due to host the triathlon mixed relay on 5 August, the Olympic marathon swimming on 8 and 9 August, and the Para-triathlon event at the Paralympics, which start on 28 August.\n\nSwimming in the river has been prohibited for over 100 years because of its high levels of pollution and the risk of disease - but French authorities have invested heavily to make the Seine swimmable as part of the Games' legacy.\n\nOrganisers said about 1.4bn euros (\u00a31.2bn) had been spent on a regeneration project to make the Seine safe.\n\nParis mayor Anne Hidalgo recently swam in the river to highlight the clean-up efforts which have been undertaken and, earlier this month, tests showed the river was clean enough for swimming.\n\nHowever, heavy rain in Paris on Friday and Saturday has caused the water quality to decline.\n\nThundery showers are forecast for Wednesday morning, following predicted high temperatures of up to 35C on Tuesday.\n\nFrance currently lags behind the European Union's average score for top-quality bathing water conditions.\n\nBetween 17-23 July, data showed that the river that dissects the French capital was suitable for have cleared the Olympic women's and men's triathlons to go ahead today after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe men's triathlon had been scheduled to take place yesterday but was postponed after the river failed water quality tests.\n\nNews that the races would go ahead came as a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries will kick off the contest at 8am Paris time (7am Irish time), with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 am Paris time, immediately after the women's race.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\nToday's races The men's event was postponed on Tuesday after tests showed the river was not safe for swimming.\n\nMen's and women's Olympic triathlon events were scheduled to take place as planned on Wednesday, organizers said, a day after the men's individual race was postponed because of pollution in the Seine.\n\nThe women's individual race was set for 8 a.m., and the rescheduled men's event for 10:45 a.m., the Olympics organizers said in a statement released before dawn on Wednesday.\n\nThe threat of postponements has lingered over Olympics events in the Seine, the river that traverses Paris, and the organizers have backup dates for triathlons and marathon swim events.\n\nThe men's triathlon race was postponed on Tuesday after heavy rain over the weekend raised the level of dangerous bacteria in the river.\n\nRepresentatives from the Paris government and other officials received the latest water quality analysis at 3:20 a.m. local time on Wednesday, the Olympics organizers said in their statement. {"uri": "8251158129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:26:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:26:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:25:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.fastcompany.com/91165044/rain-is-polluting-paris-seine-river-again-during-the-olympics", "title": "Why is the Seine too dirty for the Paris Olympics? - Fast Company", "body": "Earlier this month, Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo swam in the Seine River, a sign of the city's success cleaning up its notoriously dirty waterway ahead of the Olympics. The cleanup effort was more than just symbolic: during the Olympic Games, athletes would swim in the river for several events.\n\nBut now, at least one of those events has been postponed due to unsafe pollution levels in the Seine. The men's triathlon race, which was set to take place Tuesday morning, was postponed until July 31, according to the International Olympic Committee and World Triathlon, the governing body for the sport. Water tests \"revealed water quality levels that did not provide sufficient guarantees to allow the event to be held,\" the organizations said; Tests showed increased levels of E.coli and other potentially harmful bacteria.\n\nThe men's triathlon is now scheduled for the same day as the women's triathlon -- but both of those events, the organizations said, are \"subject to the forthcoming water tests.\" There's also a contingency day scheduled for August 2, if needed.\n\nHow is it that the Seine was safe enough for the mayor to swim in before the Olympics, but now contains potentially harmful levels of E.coli? The organizations blamed \"meteorological events beyond our control\" -- namely, the rain that fell on Paris on July 26 and 27.", "source": {"uri": "fastcompany.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8252147895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:33:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:33:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:30:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://theprint.in/environment/olympics-triathlon-races-underway-as-seine-passes-water-tests/2200085/", "title": "Olympics-Triathlon-Races underway as Seine passes water tests", "body": "The women began their race at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT), just as overnight rain was easing.\n\nThe races going ahead will be a relief for teams and athletes, as well as for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nWednesday's races were given the green light despite rain overnight.\n\nOrganisers make the call based on analysis of river samples taken the previous day at 5 a.m. and after discussions with experts on weather, according to Paris 2024.\n\nShowers started up again around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday, making racing conditions more difficult for the bike stage which features some sharp turns and a quarter of the course on cobbled roads.\n\nThe triathlon, conceived as a central showpiece of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge and takes athletes along a section of the Champs-Elysees and past monuments including the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nFifty-five women representing 34 countries kicked off the contest at 8 a.m., with France's Cassandre Beaugrand and Britain's Beth Potter, two of the top contenders for gold, diving into the river side by side from a floating pontoon next to the bridge.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nParis has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe decision to postpone the men's race at the last minute on Tuesday had triggered anger among some athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n(Reporting by Helen Reid; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": Coli and other harmful bacteria.\n\nThis setback required the race to be rescheduled to after the women's event which will start at 4pm AEST (8am local time).\n\nThe organising committee made the announcement at about 4am local time - just four hours before the scheduled start time.\n\nIn their brief statement, the World Triathlon organisation declared only, \"We will swim\" after a spate of criticism following the men's race delay.\n\nThis marks a positive turnaround for Paris 2024, after initial concerns the triathlon might need to be replaced with a duathlon due to the water quality issues.\n\nIf the Seine had not met safety standards, the event would have been converted to a duathlon format, substituting the 1500m swim with an additional 5km run.\n\nHeavy rains had previously exacerbated contamination levels, despite substantial investments of over AU$2 billion to improve water quality in the Seine.\n\nThis significant investment had included measures to ensure the triathlon and marathon swimming events could be held in clean waters.\n\nWith the triathlon set to go ahead, organisers will continue to cross their fingers for sunny weather ahead of the mixed relay scheduled for Monday.\n\nThe marathon swimming events have also been scheduled for August 8 and 9.\n\nThe organising committee will continue to provide updates to ensure athletes and spectators are Coli Concerns, Women's Triathlon Completed with Swim in the Seine River", "body": "Despite concerns about water quality in the Seine River leading to various practice cancellations and the postponement of the men's race, the women's triathlon went off without a hitch early Wednesday morning.\n\nAthletes started racing at 8 AM in Paris (2 AM EST), with the 1500m swim marking the first leg of the event.\n\nWhen all was said and done, Frenchwoman Cassandre Beaugrand crossed the finish line first in front of a home crowd in a time of 1:54:55, becoming the first French person to ever medal in the event. Switzerland's Julie Derron and Great Britain's Beth Potter rounded-out the podium.\n\nThe swim in the Seine comes as a historic moment for the nation of France. Deemed \"unswimmable\" for years, the Seine has long been a topic of debate amongst the French public. When the government, in combination with Paris 2024 Organizers, announced a $1.5 billion clean-up effort, many were skeptical about the ability to make the Seine safe to swim in. Despite the clean-up, tests taken just a month from the Olympics showed E. coli levels at 10 times the acceptable limit for swimming. However, reduced rainfall levels throughout the month of July contributed to a sharp decline in bacteria levels, leading Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo to take a plunge into the river before the start of the Games.\n\nWith conditions in the river improving, organizers were optimistic that the triathlon and open water events would be able to occur without issue, but recent downpours increased bacteria levels once-again. As a result, several triathlon training sessions were canceled early in the week, along with the men's race being postponed. Despite the hiccups, it appears as through bacteria levels have returned back under safe-swimming levels.\n\nWorld Aquatics requirements for inland waterways:\n\nWorld Triathlon requirements for inland waterways:\n\nThe men's triathalon will also occur today, with athletes slated for a 10:45 AM start in Paris. The women's event began with a 1,500m swim, in two laps with and against the current.\n\nParis 2024 organisers undertook an infrastructure improvement project of $1.5 billion to clean up the polluted water of the river.\n\nBut rainfall leading to wastewater flowing into the river affected the water quality. Heavy showers fell during the Olympics opening ceremony on Friday and steady downpour continued for the better part of Saturday.\n\nHowever, organisers had expressed confidence that despite cancellations and postponements swimming would happen in the Seine river and when Wednesday's test results showed compliance with acceptable standards it was decided to begin the competition.", {"uri": "2024-07-439292743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:23:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:23:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/triathlon-at-olympics-proceeds-in-river-seine-despite-e-coli-concerns/", "title": "Triathlon at Olympics Proceeds in River Seine Despite E.Coli Concerns - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Olympic triathlon tournaments got underway in Paris on Thursday morning, after levels of bacteria in the River Seine fell to low enough levels for the swimming leg of the contest to take place in its waters.\n\nDoubts over whether the tournaments would go ahead in the Seine as planned had become one of the hot news stories of this Olympics.\n\nThe women's race kicked off at 8 a.m. local time after the Seine's water were given the all-clear in the early hours of the morning.\n\nAs female Triathlon athletes hit the water off the Pont Alexandre III bridge in central Paris, it marked the culmination of an ambitious $1.5B (\u20ac1.4B) plan by the city of Paris to clean up the river's notoriously polluted waters so that it could host key endurance swimming events during the Olympics.\n\nParis City Mayor Anne Hidalgo hopes the scheme will have the lasting legacy of allowing Parisians to swim in the Seine, which has been off-limits for bathers for the best part of a century.\n\nIn a bid to prove that the waters had been cleaned up to a sufficient level for the Olympic contests to take place, Hidalgo even took a dip herself in the lead-up to the 2024 games.\n\nUnseasonably heavy rains on the night of the opening ceremony on Friday (July 26) which continued into Saturday had pushed bacteria above unacceptable levels. This led to the men's race being postponed on Tuesday.\n\nStorm warnings over Paris for late Tuesday, early Wednesday gave rise to fears that the bacteria levels would rise further and that the Triathlon would be reduced to a Duathlon instead.\n\nHowever, in spite of heavy rain in the early hours of Wednesday morning, the World Triathlon and International Olympics Committee announced at 4.00 a.m. local time that the women's race would go ahead, followed by the mens rescheduled race.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" they said in a statement.\n\nThe men's race is now due to take place at 10.45 a.m. local time.\n\nThe Paris triathlon encompasses a 1,500m swim with and against the current of the river, followed by 40km bike and 10km running legs around central Paris.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8251646783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:09:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:09:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:08:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/triathlons-set-to-proceed-in-paris-after-clean-water-results-from-the-seine/", "title": "Triathlons Set to Proceed in Paris After Clean Water Results from the Seine - The Global Herald", "body": "The upcoming Olympic triathlon events for men and women will proceed as scheduled on Wednesday, thanks to successful water quality tests conducted on the River Seine.\n\nThese developments come after earlier concerns arose, particularly following the postponement of the men's triathlon event on Tuesday due to unacceptable water quality levels.\n\nPrior to the latest updates, event organizers indicated that the conditions were uncertain, with only a 60% likelihood of the triathlons occurring without further incident.\n\nTest results from early Wednesday morning confirmed that the water met the requirements set by World Triathlon, paving the way for the events to be held as planned.\n\nAmong the competitors, Great Britain's Alex Yee is anticipated to contend for gold in the men's race, while his teammate Beth Potter holds the title of the reigning women's world champion.\n\nWith the confirmation of water quality suitable for swimming, previously aired worries regarding a potential transition to a duathlon format (which would exclude the swimming segment) have been alleviated.\n\nDaily assessments of the Seine's water quality have been implemented due to the impact of recent heavy rainfall, which had resulted in poor water conditions.\n\nIn fact, several early water quality checks during the games led to the cancellation of swimming training sessions due to concerns over contamination. However, organizers maintained optimism that the triathlon events would occur as planned.\n\nContinuous monitoring of the Seine's water quality is crucial, especially with the upcoming mixed relay triathlon on August 5, the marathon swimming events scheduled for August 8 and 9, and the Para-triathlon at the Paralympics beginning August 28.\n\nHistorically, swimming in the Seine has been banned for over a century owing to its severe pollution and hazards to public health. Nonetheless, substantial investments have been made by local authorities to improve the river's condition, aimed at making it safe for swimming as part of the Olympic legacy.\n\nApproximately 1.4 billion euros has been allocated to various regeneration projects aimed at restoring the Seine's ecosystem. In a show of confidence regarding the efforts, Paris mayor Anne Hidalgo recently swam in the river, emphasizing the improvements made.\n\nDespite these advances, rain over the weekend has adversely affected the water quality, and further thundershowers are anticipated for Wednesday morning, following heatwave conditions that could reach up to 35\u00b0C on Tuesday.\n\nCurrently, France's water quality ratings fall short of the European Union's standards for top recreational water quality. Data from July 17-23 indicated that the Seine met swimming standards for six out of the seven days, yet just last June, E. coli levels were found to exceed acceptable limits by a significant margin.", {"uri": "8251390260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:49:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:49:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:48:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.themarysue.com/olympic-triathalon-swimming-in-seine-under-threat-of-being-canceled/", "title": "The, Ahem, Sh**ty Reason Why Swimming Could Be Canceled in Olympics Triathlon Event", "body": "Hosting the Olympics is a matter of great pride and responsibility for any country, and that be said for France, which has carried out the duties for the 2024 event fairly well so far (with a couple of massive exceptions).\n\nHowever, despite their best attempts, the French are currently struggling to hold an event in the river Seine due to well, ahem, sh**ty reasons. The men's triathlon event, which was supposed to take place on Tuesday, has now been moved to Wednesday due to the alarming quantity of E. coli and other bacteria in the water body.\n\nThis will make the men's competition clash with the women's event, which is also scheduled to take place the same day. Friday has been kept as a reserve day, but as things stand, it is looking more likely that the swimming segment of the event will be canceled.\n\nThe country has invested heavily in ensuring that the beautiful but notoriously unhygienic river remains in pristine state throughout the competition, pumping in $1.5 billion and overlooking a massive cleaning drive. However, there has been little to no effect on the bacteria levels in the waterway that runs through France's capital. The swimming portion of the triathlon is not the only event under threat, as the river is also in line to host the marathon swimming competition next week.\n\nThe weather Paris has experienced in recent days has only made matters worse, with rain accentuating the overflow of the city's domestic water system, leading to the impurity levels in the Seine compounding. To make matters worse, there is a rain forecast predicted in the city from Tuesday night through Thursday.\n\nThe Olympics officials are hoping for clear skies and hot and dry weather in the upcoming days, which might lead to water tests showing a tolerable amount of E. coli and other bacteria. Coli-Polluted Seine River", "body": "Olympics Organizers Deny 'Last Supper' Reference in Opening Ceremony: 'Never an Intention to Show Disrespect to Any Religious Group' 2 days ago\n\nUPDATE- After being postponed on Tuesday due to pollution in the Seine river, the Olympics's triathlon swimming competition took place on Wednesday morning. Both the women's and men's races are going ahead today, ending a long saga involving daily water tests measuring levels of a faecal bacteria known as E. coli.\n\n\"Following a meeting on water quality held on 31 July at 3.30am attended by Paris 2024, representatives of World Triathlon and their Technical and Medical Delegates, M\u00e9t\u00e9o France, the City of Paris and the Prefecture of the \u00cele-de-France Region involved in carrying out water quality tests, the stakeholders involved have confirmed that the women's and the men's triathlons will go ahead as planned on 31 July at 8am and 10.45am respectively,\" read the official statement released by Paris 2024 organizers.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20am, have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" the statement continued.\n\nThe subject of a running joke since the release of Xavier Gens' hit shark movie \"Under Paris\" on Netflix, the Seine was supposed to be clean enough for the Triathlon and Marathon competitions since the beginning the Games. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo had pledged to make the water quality safe enough for athletes and locals to swim in it many months ago. The ambitious project to clean the notoriously toxic river cost more than $1.5 billion, but it was soon plagued by scorn and even a social media campaign #JeChieDansLaSeine, which encouraged Parisians to defecate in the water earlier this month.\n\nThe Paris mayor took a swim in the Seine (wearing a wetsuit and goggles) on July 17 alongside Tony Estanguet, the gold medal-winning French slalom canoeist who presides over the Olympics organizing committee, to drum up enthusiasm and show that it was safe enough. But it turns out that the Seine was still highly polluted.\n\nLocal media outlets have reported that the heavy rains on July 26 - mainly during the opening ceremony -- have ramped up the levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the Seine. That had already caused two training days (on Sunday and Monday) to be canceled. The mixed team relay is set for Aug. 5.\n\nThe pouring rain during the opening ceremony also forced Lady Gaga to pre-tape her performance for safety reasons. Maud le Pladec, the choreographer and head of dance for the Olympics and Paralympics who worked with Gaga for many months, said her show was nearly called off due to the weather conditions.", {"uri": "8251919279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:04:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:04:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:03:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/olympic-triathlons-to-proceed-after-seine-water-quality-improves/", "title": "Olympic Triathlons To Proceed After Seine Water Quality Improves", "body": "July 31, (THEWILL) - The Olympic women's and men's triathlons were given the green light to take place on Wednesday, following improved water quality tests in the Seine River. This decision ended days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim would be viable after heavy rainfall.\n\nThe men's event, originally scheduled for Tuesday, was postponed due to failed water quality tests. The announcement that both races would go ahead on Wednesday brought relief to teams, athletes, and Paris authorities who have promised a swimmable Seine as a long-term Olympic legacy.\n\nDespite overnight rain, organisers approved the races based on river samples taken the previous day and after discussions with weather experts. The triathlon, a central feature of the Paris Olympics, starts and finishes at the Alexandre III bridge, taking athletes along the Champs-Elysees and past landmarks like the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nThe women's race, featuring 55 athletes from 34 countries, began earlier, with top contenders Cassandre Beaugrand of France and Beth Potter of Britain starting side by side. The men's event followed later.\n\nParis has invested 1.4 billion euros in wastewater infrastructure to improve river water quality. However, the decision to hold the triathlon in the Seine has been criticised by some athletes, with Belgium's Marten Van Riel expressing frustration over the last-minute changes and questioning the prioritisation of athlete health.", "source": {"uri": "thewillnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "THEWILL NEWS MEDIA - Nigeria News, Nigeria Politics, Breaking News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "https://thewillnews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/IMG_1431.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9776638", "eventUri": "eng-9776638", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-31", "textStart": 0, "textEnd": 7}], "sentiment": 0.09019607843137245, "wgt": 145, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251146957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:17:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:17:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:15:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5665630/2024/07/30/paris-2024-olympic-triathlon-duathlon/", "title": "Explained: Could Olympic triathlon become a duathlon - and who would that favour?", "body": "For all the gold and glory of the first week of the Paris Olympics, one major headache for organisers has simply refused to fade: the River Seine.\n\nAfter days -- indeed, months -- of concerns about water quality, their worst fears were realised when the men's triathlon -- due to be held today -- was postponed until Wednesday.\n\nBut an even bigger problem looms: if the situation does not improve, there is the doomsday scenario of both races being scheduled for Friday as duathlons, with the swimming event removed entirely.\n\nThe Athletic analyses how we reached this point, and what impact that decision could have on the event.\n\nPut simply, the water quality in the Seine, where the swimming part of the triathlon is due to take place, is deemed to be unsafe.\n\nDespite pre-Games investment of more than \u00a31.2billion (\u20ac1.4bn) to clean up the river, levels of E. coli and other bacteria in the water spiked to dangerous levels following heavy rainfall at the end of last week.\n\nParis' combined sewer system, which sees both wastewater and stormwater travel through the same pipes, means that large quantities of rain can make pipes exceed capacity, with untreated wastewater overflowing into the Seine.\n\nWith thunderstorms and heavy rain expected from 6pm local time on Tuesday evening, there is further risk of contaminated water.\n\nThe men's triathlon is now due to take place on Wednesday morning (10.45am French time; 5.45am ET) following the conclusion of the women's event (7am French time; 2am ET), but only if the water passes safety tests.\n\nIf it fails again, organisers could need to resort to staging the events on the reserve day on Friday, but with the triathlons becoming duathlons -- just made up of the cycling and running events.\n\nThis would be an unprecedented change at such a major event, although there were water quality problems in Paris a year ago for the test events. The mixed team relay and para-triathlon both became duathlons.\n\nAfter that, World Triathon said that the contingency plan for Paris, if water quality was poor, was to make the triathlon a duathlon but insisted that was \"an unlikely event\".\n\nMayor Anne Hidalgo, and a few dozen volunteers, felt comfortable swimming in the Seine before the Games began to showcase the improved water quality but heavy storms such as the ones witnessed in Paris last week always threatened to be disruptive.\n\nCompletely.\n\nAn Olympic triathlon consists of a 1,500m open-water swim followed by a 40-kilometre cycle and ending with a 10km run. Typically a duathlon would entail a 40km cycle and a 10km run, but if the triathlon was to become a duathlon, there would be a 5km run in place of the 1.5km swim to start, with the rest remaining the same.\n\n\"Physiologically, you're coming onto the bike with more fatigued legs (after a run instead of a swim),\" says Andrew Woodroffe, a performance triathlon coach. \"Swimming tires you out before you get on the bike but it's not the same speed or intensity which these athletes will be running at.\n\n\"If you remove the swim, it completely changes the dynamic of the event. Running is what damages the legs. The men will run well under 15 minutes, they're running so fast. When it comes to the final run, their legs will be fried.\n\n\"The fastest swimmers don't tend to win because they're not as good runners. Stopping the swim makes it more of a race and maybe makes it more of a level playing field. But it's simply a different sport.\"\n\nMark Buckingham, a triathlon coach and former duathlon world medallist who is the national coach for Triathlon Ireland, agrees. \"Not many athletes go in with the mindset that it might be a duathlon, so it'll catch people off guard,\" he said. \"Quite a few will have trained specifically so their swim will be on point.\n\n\"In a typical triathlon, the strongest swimmers would swim as hard as they can, jump on the bike, get a small group working together and try to create a gap and hang on in the run.\n\n\"In a duathlon, the best runners will be at the front and there will be a bigger pack on the bike because the fast runners have already outrun the slower runners and they have no incentive to break away because they might as well sit in the pack wheel-to-wheel (and expend less energy than breaking away) and just wait for the second run.\"\n\n\"It's a mess,\" says Woodroffe. \"This is the Olympic triathlon. It will make it a bit of a mockery and it's brutal for the athletes. It's very amateur. You wouldn't expect it at the Olympic Games. It'll be talked about for a very long time, but it won't make duathlon a more popular sport.\"\n\nBuckingham says it would be \"sad\" if it becomes a duathlon and points out that it would ensure this year's Olympic event would \"forever have an asterisk next to it.\"\n\nAfter the success of the Tokyo Games three years ago, when a mixed relay event was added to the triathlon programme, there are fears this would set the sport back and anger over the damage to the sport's image.\n\n\"It's terrible for triathlon,\" Buckingham added. \"We want to see it in the Olympic Games. Moving forward, it might wake up organisers to the potential water quality at other events and make them plan more effectively. It seems like every other week we hear of dirty water athletes have to swim in. A duathlon is not even close to a reasonable contingency.\"\n\nWorld Triathlon president Marisol Casado has suggested there is a \"60-40\" chance of the triathlon events taking place on Wednesday.\n\n\"We really want this to happen. But, of course, we really thought that this recuperation [the improvement in the water quality] would be faster than it was,\" she said. \"We were shocked this morning when we saw that it was not as fast as we wanted.\"\n\nAurelie Merle, executive director of sports competitions at Paris 2024, added: \"The priority of the IOC, of Paris 2024, is for the health of the athletes, and the tests that were carried out on the Seine were not sufficient on the entirety of the course.\"\n\nChanging the race's format could dramatically alter the prospects of who comes away with gold medals.\n\n\"Hayden Wilde from New Zealand and Morgan Pearson from the USA run well,\" says Woodroffe. \"Alex Yee and Kristian Blummenfelt will take the run out very fast. It could be a lot closer on the bike. The difference will be whose legs are cooked for the 10km.\n\n\"On the women's side, the race would split up a lot more because the running times are much wider apart. It would be less of a spectacle for the women.\"\n\nBuckingham says, inevitably, the stronger runners in the triathlon would benefit from the elimination of the swimming event.\n\n\"Yee, Blummenfelt and Wilde -- the medallists from Tokyo -- it wouldn't affect them as much because they are all strong runners,\" he said. \"The same with Beth Potter and Cassandre Beaugrand in the women's race -- they finished first and second in the test event last year and are exceptional runners.\n\n\"Pearson from the USA runs really well. He might make it into the mix. He might soak up that first run better and may not have quite the same problems with cramp, heat stress and fatigue, which they will all suffer from. It subtly brings one or two people into it more. Of the top 10, about 70 per cent would be the same with a duathlon or a triathlon.\n\n\"It will change the result but the favourites will still be favourites. In the women's triathlon, Leonie Periault, who is a class athlete, would be more in contention for a medal. The athletes who can soak up the first run tend to do the best.\"\n\nSort of. The heating of the planet due to human-induced climate change is increasing the intensity of rainfall and that results in more polluted rivers.\n\n\"The climate has changed that we are facing. In some cases we have waves that are too high, in other moments we have electrical storms,\" Casado said.\n\nMerle also pointed to the unusually large total rainfall. \"We had meteorological events beyond our control,\" she said. \"The equivalent to July's rainfall fell in just 36 hours. It's taken time for the river to get back to normal.\"\n\nThat could not be accounted for in a matter of days, but the state of the Seine over time is something that was within the control of the city, hence the decision to spend so much trying to clean up the river and prevent discharges from reaching it in the first place.\n\nMany athletes, present and former, have been dismayed at the lack of a contingency plan involving another venue.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgian triathlete Marten Van Riel wrote on Instagram.\n\nHe added that organisers had been \"disrespectful to the years of preparation of the athletes and to all our fans that were going to watch live or on TV. What an appearance for triathlon on the biggest scene.\"\n\nThose sentiments were echoed by Vicky Holland, who won bronze for Great Britain at the 2016 Olympics.\n\n\"A duathlon would be the worst-case scenario,\" Holland told the BBC. \"That would be a really disappointing outcome. It is disappointing that there wasn't another contingency in place, but a backup venue feels like an obvious option.\"\n\nThe marathon swimming event may be relocated to the rowing course at Vaires-sur-Marne should the Seine still be considered unsafe, but that would be less practical for a triathlon.\n\n\"There's a spot 40km from Paris where they've done open-water swimming,\" says Woodroffe. \"There's a big triathlon series -- the French Grand Prix -- who do an event a few kilometres from Paris with an open swim. A lot of talk within triathlon circles has been, 'Why didn't they just use this venue?'\n\n\"They could swim there, then cycle into the city centre, because they want the city-centre thing. The Seine seems to have been a passion project. If you've got the surfing in Tahiti and French Polynesia, then you can probably do the triathlon a few kilometres outside Paris.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8251177833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:43:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:43:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:42:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://brobible.com/sports/article/olympics-controversy-triathlon-seine-sewage-bacteria-marten-van-riel/", "title": "Triathletes Torch Olympics Over Sewage Disaster", "body": "Marten Van Riel is a legitimate medal contender in the men's triathlon at the Olympics but he will have to wait at least one more day to compete after Tuesday's event was postponed. He is absolutely furious with how this entire sewage-based saga has gone down over the last few days, weeks and months.\n\nThe athletes are forced to sit around and wait for an event that may or may not happen as planned -- or at all.\n\nFrance spent $1.5 billion (!!) to clean up the Seine in Paris ahead of the Olympics. Not only did the famous \"river\" play a huge role in the Opening Ceremonies, it is supposed to host then swimming leg of the men's and women's triathlon as well as the swimming marathon.\n\nHowever, swimming in the Seine has been illegal for more than 120 years due to fecal bacteria. Heavy rains overwhelm Paris' infrastructure and literal sewage leaks into the city's most famous body of water.\n\nThe expensive cleanup effort was an epic failure. Open water swing practice was canceled on Sunday and Monday due to unsafe conditions. The men's triathlon on Tuesday was also postponed to Wednesday.\n\nIf bumping it back by one day doesn't work, which it certainly seems like it will not based on the forecast for the week, they'll hold the men's and women's competitions on Friday. If it is not safe to swim in the Seine by Friday, the Olympics will hold the triathlon as a duathlon -- with only biking and running.\n\nParis officials refused to apologize to the athletes and blamed conditions outside of their control, weather and climate change, for the high levels of E. coli. They also said that a downgrade to a duathlon would not be unfair to any athletes, even though they prepared for a triathlon and some athletes are better in the water than on land.\n\nMarten Van Riel had/has hopes to podium in the men's triathlon after finishing sixth in Rio and fourth in Tokyo. The 31-year-old Belgian athlete is furious with how this entire situation has been handled and responded back to World Triathlon's announcement of postponement on Instagram.", "source": {"uri": "brobible.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BroBible"}, "authors": [{"uri": "grayson_weir@brobible.com", "name": "Grayson Weir", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251791210", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:25:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:25:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:24:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/paris-olympics-2024/paris-olympics-triathlon-races-get-a-go-ahead-as-seine-river-passes-water-quality-tests/articleshow/112155946.cms", "title": "Paris Olympics Triathlon: Races get a go-ahead as Seine river passes water-quality tests | Paris Olympics 2024 News - Times of India", "body": "The Olympic women's and men's triathlons have been given the green light to proceed on Wednesday, following the latest water quality tests of the Seine river. The tests revealed that bacterial levels had decreased, putting an end to the uncertainty surrounding the feasibility of the central Paris swim after heavy rainfall.\n\nOriginally slated for Tuesday, the men's triathlon was rescheduled to Wednesday due to the river failing to meet the required water quality standards.\n\nPARIS OLYMPICS LIVE UPDATES: DAY 5\n\nThe confirmation that the races will take place on Wednesday has brought relief to the teams, athletes and Paris authorities. The city has made a commitment to its residents to ensure a swimmable Seine as a lasting legacy of the Olympic Games, with the triathlon serving as a highly visible assessment of this promise.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received this news,\" Benjamin Maze, technical director for France's triathlon federation, told Reuters. \"Now that we know we will race, we can mentally switch fully into competition mode.\"\n\nThe triathlon races scheduled for Wednesday were allowed to proceed despite the overnight rainfall. The decision to continue with the event was made by the organizers after analyzing river samples collected at 5 a.m. the previous day and consulting with weather experts, as stated by Paris 2024.\n\nHowever, the weather conditions took a turn for the worse as showers resumed around 5:45 a.m. on Wednesday. The rainfall made the cycling stage more challenging for the athletes, as the course includes sharp turns and a significant portion on cobbled roads.\n\nThe triathlon, which is considered a centerpiece event of the Paris Olympics, commences and concludes at the Alexandre III bridge. The route takes the competitors along the famous Champs-Elysees and past iconic landmarks such as the Musee d'Orsay.\n\nThe women's race, featuring 55 athletes from 34 nations, is set to begin at 8 a.m. (0600 GMT). Two of the top contenders for the gold medal, Cassandre Beaugrand from France and Beth Potter from Britain, will start the race side by side, diving into the river from a floating pontoon adjacent to the bridge.\n\nFollowing the conclusion of the women's race, the men's event will commence at 10:45 a.m.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said in a statement.\n\nThe city of Paris has invested a substantial sum of 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) in public funds to upgrade its wastewater infrastructure. The goal is to effectively manage sewage and reduce spillage into the river. In an effort to allay concerns about water quality, Mayor Anne Hidalgo recently took a swim, aiming to reassure skeptics that the water poses no health risks.\n\nHowever, the last-minute decision to postpone the men's race on Tuesday sparked frustration and disappointment among some of the participating athletes.\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes, this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago,\" Belgium's Marten Van Riel wrote on World Triathlon's Instagram page.\n\n\"We are just puppets in a puppet show.\"\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. From running live blogs for India and non-India cricket matches to global spectacles featuring Indian talents, like the Chess World Cup final featuring Praggnanandhaa and the Badminton World Championships semifinal featuring HS Prannoy, our live coverage extends to all mega sporting events. We extensively cover events like the Olympics, Asian Games, Cricket World Cups, FIFA World Cups, and more. The desk is also adept at writing comprehensive match reports and insightful post-match commentary, complemented by stats-based articles that provide an in-depth analysis of player performances and team dynamics. We track news wires for key stories, conduct exclusive player interviews in both text and video formats, and file content from print editions and reporters. We keep track of all viral stories, trending topics and produce our own copies on the subjects. Wednesday after the latest Seine river water tests showed lower levels of bacteria, ending days of uncertainty over whether the central Paris swim was viable after heavy rains.\n\nThe decision came as a relief for the athletes expecting to compete and for Paris authorities who have promised residents a swimmable Seine as a long-term legacy of the Games, with the triathlon a very public test.\n\n\"The results of the latest water analyses, received at 3.20 a.m., have been assessed as compliant by World Triathlon allowing for the triathlon competitions to take place,\" Paris 2024 and the top contenders for gold, set to dive into the river side by side.\n\nThe men's event will take place at 10:45 a.m., immediately after the women's race.\n\n\"It is with great joy that we received spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.52 billion) of public money on wastewater infrastructure to contain sewage and minimise spillage into the river, and Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip earlier this month in a bid to convince doubters that the water will not make them ill.\n\nThe gamble that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon was never guaranteed to pay off as water quality varies widely day-to-day, with rainfall causing concentrations of infection-causing bacteria like E. coli to rise.\n\n($1 = 0.9240 euros) (Reporting by Helen Reid; Editing by Peter Rutherford )", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251720609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:22:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:22:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:21:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://blueprint.ng/mens-triathlon-postponed-over-poor-water-quality/", "title": "Men's triathlon postponed over poor water quality - Blueprint Newspapers Limited", "body": "The Olympic men's individual triathlon at Paris 2024 has been postponed after tests revealed water quality in the River Seine did not reach the required standard.\n\nThe race was due to start at 07:00 BST (08:00 local time) on Tuesday and will now take place on Wednesday at 09:45 (10:45 local time), following the conclusion of the women's event.\n\nSwimming training sessions were cancelled on Sunday and Monday because of the water quality, which was impacted by recent heavy rainfall.\n\nFriday, 2 August remains a contingency date for both races, while organisers have said the event could be contested as a duathlon as a last resort.\n\n\"Tests carried out in the Seine today revealed water quality did not provide sufficient guarantees to allow the event to be held,\" World Triathlon said.\n\n\"Despite the improvement in the water quality levels, the readings at some points of the swim course are still above the acceptable limits.\"\n\nGreat Britain's Alex Yee is one of the favourites for gold in the men's race, while team-mate Beth Potter is the reigning women's world champion.\n\nTests are being carried out daily on the water quality in the Seine, which is also due to host the triathlon mixed relay on 5 August, the Olympic marathon swimming on 8 and 9 August, and the Para-triathlon event at the Paralympics, which start on 28 August.\n\nOrganisers said about 1.4bn euros (\u00a31.2bn) has been spent on a regeneration project to make the Seine safe to swim in after a 100-year-old ban from doing so.\n\nBut as recently as June this year the level of E coli {"uri": "2024-07-438980684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:40:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/explained-sports/paris-olympics-triathlon-event-river-seines-water-quality-sewage-system-water-treatment-plants-9485616/", "title": "Why seine's water quality poses a challenge for the Olympics", "body": "The swimming leg of the men's triathlon event in the ongoing Paris Olympics was postponed on Tuesday, over concerns regarding River Seine's water quality. In the run-up to the Games, organisers had spent over a billion dollars to improve the river's condition. The Seine has long been polluted, so much so, that swimming in the Seine had been banned since 1923.\n\nParis' aged sewage system is designed such that rainwater and wastewater flow through the same pipes. During heavy rain, these pipes reach their capacity and overflow, leading to untreated sewage being directly discharged into the Seine instead of first going to a treatment plant.\n\nMoreover, rains also lead the Seine to be inundated with wildlife like rodents. \"When it rains a lot, all of that from those animals can end up in the Seine,\" Dr Nicole Iovine, an infectious disease specialist at the University of Florida Health in Gainesville, told the Associated Press.\n\nA major issue is the concentration of the bacteria E. coli in the river. Found in the faecal waste of humans and other animals, some strains of the bacteria can cause severe illness, including gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections (UTIs). E. coli concentration levels are measured in colony-forming units (cfu). Up to 900 cfu per 100 ml of water is considered safe for competitions, per standards set by the European Union and the World Triathlon Federation. Following heavy rains, the Seine's E. coli levels often exceeded this threshold, sometimes by a factor of two.\n\nA billion-dollar plan\n\nTo fix the Seine's pollution problem, Paris has spent 1.4 billion euros ($1.53 billion). In fact, key to Paris' winning bid for the 2024 Games was a major environmental overhaul of the city. This included a promise to ensure that Olympic athletes could swim in the iconic river, much like they had done in 1900 -- the last time Paris hosted the Olympics.\n\nCentral to the city's efforts to fix the Seine was the creation of a giant underground rainwater storage tank in southeastern Paris, capable of holding enough water to fill 20 Olympic-size swimming pools. Planners believed this would hold runoff water during heavy rains, the sewage system from getting overwhelmed.\n\nThe city also attempted to renovate the sewage system and upgrade its water treatment plants. But heavy rains can still overwhelm the system and contaminate the river -- as we see now.\n\nThe alternatives\n\nThe triathlon swimming events were scheduled for July 30 and 31, and August 5, while the marathon swimming events (also to be held in the Seine) are to be held on August 8 and 9. Water quality tests are mandatory 48 hours before each race. Reserve days have been kept for the water quality to improve.\n\nFor marathon swimming, the Vaires-sur-Marne Nautical Stadium near Paris has been kept as an alternative venue. If the Seine remains, the swimming leg of the triathlons may be cancelled.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438808834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:56:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:56:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/prioritising-scenery-over-water-safety-could-mean-the-olympic-triathlon-is-downgraded-to-a-duathlon-13187721", "title": "Prioritising scenery over water safety could mean the Olympic triathlon is downgraded to a duathlon", "body": "Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player\n\nWhen it requires daily checks to see if water can just about meet safety threshold - why take the risk at all?\n\nPromoting Paris seemed the priority when selecting the location for Olympic triathlons swimming events, events that might now have to be cut completely.\n\nAll that money poured into trying to clean up the River Seine - more than \u00a31bn - and still they could not prepare for rain deluging Paris at the worst time and increasing the E.coli bacteria in the polluted water.\n\n\"We are not God, we are not controlling the weather,\" World Triathlon president Marisol Casado told Sky News, having blamed climate change for the storms since Friday's opening ceremony drenching the French capital.\n\nRead more: Why the Seine is too polluted\n\nSewage and stormwater can flow through the same pipes if they are overwhelmed by rain that organisers did not see coming in the weeks before the Olympics.\n\nSo they are left sweating on the water quality readings from constant testing as storms returned to Paris tonight.\n\nToo dirty and dangerous were the results for the previous two days, preventing any swimming training sessions ahead of the triathlon.\n\nDespite that, organisers still went to bed on Monday night trying to stage the triathlon the next morning.\n\nThe crucial round of tests on the water were conducted at 3.30am and, once the results were in, athletes were given less than three hours' notice that the men's triathlon had been postponed.\n\n\"The tests show it is unhealthy for people to swim in,\" Ms Casado reported back.\n\n\"We are taking care of that. We are not going to let them swim unless the water is good quality.\"\n\nFurther down the river from the Pont Alexandre III Bridge start and finish line, at the offices of water analysts Fluidion, we found water intelligence experts testing the latest batch from the Seine as part of constant monitoring.\n\nIn the laboratory, samples from three different spots on the river were there, ready for rapid tests.\n\nFluidion chief executive Dan Angelescu showed us two samples being incubated.\n\n\"They develop optical signals that allow us to obtain a signal curve,\" he explained to Sky News. \"And by analysing the signal curve, we can actually determine after how long the fluorescence appears in the samples. And this is what's related to the number of bacteria in there.\n\n\"By looking at the sample over time and collecting plenty of data on multiple optical channels, we can determine the number of bacteria that were there initially when we started the measurement.\"\n\nFar from a Paris-only problem\n\nThe quality of open waters for sports is far from a unique problem for Paris.\n\nRowers in the Oxford-Cambridge boat race in April this year complained about pollution in the River Thames and sickness was blamed on an outbreak of E.coli.\n\nBut there have been concerns about the Seine's water safety, with swimming banned in 1923 - a year before the Olympics were last staged in Paris.\n\n\"What is dangerous is that when you have sewage that overflows into the river, you'll get all the pathogens that are associated with it,\" Mr Angelescu said.\n\n\"So it's not the bacteria we measure that are necessarily dangerous, but it is all the pathogens that are coming with it.\n\n\"And those could be viruses, other types of bacteria, they could be protozoa, etc.\n\n\"So this is where the danger comes from. And what we measure is a way to quantify the risk by looking at E. coli, which is one of the bacteria that you find in the human digestive tract. But the danger comes from pretty much everything else that's out there associated with it.\"\n\nParis tried to clean up the contaminated water to provide a triathlon venue giving landmarks and monuments even greater prominence in the coverage.\n\nBut was scenery prioritised over safety considerations in trying to secure a route?\n\n\"This is very important specifically for our athletes - it's very important just to showcase,\" Ms Casado said. \"It is very important because for me ours are the best athletes in the village, let's say. And they require a wonderful space.\"\n\nToday, the Seine was too risky to swim in. {"uri": "2024-07-438806194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:51:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:51:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:46:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/sports/article290589639.html", "title": "Poor water quality forced the postponement of the men's triathlon. Will Ivan Puskovitch get to swim the Seine?", "body": "By Mike Sielski, The Philadelphia Inquirer The Tribune Content Agency\n\nPARIS - In the wake of a rainstorm Friday that dampened the Olympics' opening ceremony and deteriorated the Seine River's water quality, Olympic organizers postponed the men's triathlon on Tuesday, raising doubts about when and whether the outdoor swimming events at the Games will be contested.\n\nThe triathlon was scheduled to go off at 8 a.m. Paris time. But 4 1/2 hours earlier, after testing the Seine's water, representatives from the International Olympic Committee, World Triathlon and the City of Paris, among other determining bodies, decided early that the race needed to be pushed back to 10:45 a.m. Wednesday. The women's triathlon remains scheduled for 8 a.m. Wednesday.\n\nBoth of those competition dates, however, \"are subject to the forthcoming water tests complying with the established World Triathlon thresholds for swimming,\" according to a statement released by World Triathlon. The original contingency date of Friday for both triathlon events remains in place.\n\n\"Paris 2024 and World Triathlon reiterate that their priority is the health of the athletes,\" World Triathlon's statement read in part. \"The tests carried out in the Seine today revealed water quality levels that did not provide sufficient guarantees to allow the event to be held.\"\n\nThe postponement is hardly surprising, given the challenges that the Seine's conditions posed and the spotty history of the Olympics' open-water events. Paris spent a reported $1.5 billion (in American dollars) to try to clean the Seine, but swimming has been illegal in the river for more than a century, and rain often leads to rising levels of E. coli and other contaminants. Problems related to pollution and water impurity plagued previous Summer Games in Tokyo, Rio de Janeiro and Sydney.\n\nIvan Puskovitch is scheduled to compete in the men's marathon swimming event on Aug. 9. Weeks before the Summer Games began, he, his family and his coaches expressed concerns about the quality of the Seine's water and the possibility that the Olympics' open-water events would either have to be moved indoors or prove altogether unsafe.\n\n\"I think about that a lot,\" Puskovitch said in May. \"I would really love to race in the Seine. It's so iconic. {"uri": "8251924862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:08:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:08:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:07:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/olympics-news-paris-olympics-hit-by-e-coli-crisis-after-1-5-billion-seine-river-cleanup-triathletes-and-sports-world-raises-concern/", "title": "Paris Olympics Hit by E. Coli Crisis After $1.5 Billion Seine River Cleanup; Triathletes and Sports World Raises Concern", "body": "Jul 30, 2024; Paris, France; A general view of the Seine river after the men\u00eds triathlon was postponed during the Paris 2024 Olympic Summer Games at Grand Palais-Pont Alexandre III. Mandatory Credit: Andrew Nelles-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe lead-up to the Paris Olympics was filled with excitement among competing athletes and sports fans worldwide. The French government invested $1.5 billion to clean up the Seine River for the triathlon events.\n\nHowever, as reported by Joe Pompliano in his LinkedIn newsletter, these activities have recently been canceled due to elevated E. coli levels. This issue represents one of the most significant setbacks in Olympic history and a major disaster for the organizers.\n\nThe Seine River clean-up was no simple task, given Paris's age and the difficulty of updating older infrastructure. A project was implemented to collect sewer waste in a giant basin before it could contaminate the river. However, this system proved vulnerable to overflow during rainfall, leading to direct contamination of the Seine.\n\nInitially, the project seemed successful, with Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo even swimming in the river to demonstrate confidence in the clean-up efforts. Unfortunately, rain during the opening ceremony caused the river to become contaminated once again.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee (IOC) has been testing the water daily, but with consistently poor results and upcoming rains predicted, they are now considering modifying the triathlon to a duathlon, eliminating the swimming portion.\n\nThis situation has sparked outrage online, with athletes and fans criticizing the mishandling of the event preparations.\n\nFans and athletes alike were looking forward to the Paris Olympics. However, due to the government's negligence, everyone is forced to endure this difficult moment, causing widespread outrage.\n\nWhen World Triathlon shared an Instagram post about the matter, one of Belgium's biggest triathletes, Marten Van Riel, expressed his dissatisfaction, stating:\n\n\"If the priority was the health of the athletes this event would have been moved to another location a long time ago. We are just puppets in a puppetshow.\"\n\nHe continued, writing:\n\n\"Duathlon is no triathlon and changing the day like that in the middle of the night is disrespectful to the years of preparation of the athletes and to all (y)our fans that were going to watch live or on tv. What an appearance for triathlon on the biggest scene!\"\n\nBob Babbitt, a veteran of the sport, recalls another incident in triathlon competitions and compares how the surfing association decided to relocate the event from Paris.\n\n\"In the last Olympics somehow a huge boat was in the way and for the first time in my 40 + years in the sport there was a false start. This time around World Triathlon had four years to come up with a Plan B. The leaders of Surfing, which is only in it's second Olympic Games, made the decision to move to Tahiti to showcase their sport and their athletes in the best light possible.\"\n\nHe continued, writing:\n\n\"World Triathlon decided to put their athletes at risk and pray that a disgusting body of water would somehow clean itself up overnight. I feel awful for these amazing athletes who have spent their lives preparing for these Olympic Games and now have to hope and pray that they actually get to race a triathlon tomorrow!\"\n\nBritish triathlete Max Stapley has also expressed his dissatisfaction with the management.\n\n\"Pathetic, 0 respect for athlete welfare and investment. Not being able to hold a triathlon in the country with the most tried and tested venues in the world is inexcusable.\"\n\nNew Zealand's Chris Dunn also expressed the same emotion as his fellow triathletes.\n\n\"The river has been un-swimmable for 100 years. One more day will fix it [facepalm emoji]\"\n\nThe World Triathlon will convene with the organizers to determine the fate of the events as soon as possible, with an official statement to follow.", {"uri": "8252054919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:34:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:34:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:33:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/article-after-postponement-and-worries-over-cleanliness-of-the-seine-triathlon/", "title": "After postponement and worries over cleanliness of the Seine, triathlon finally goes off at Paris 2024", "body": "Nobody's skin turned green and no one appeared to get sick, at least not from the water.\n\nAfter one postponement and many weeks of worry about water pollution, the triathlon competition finally got underway at the Paris Olympics Wednesday morning with 55 athletes in the women's event plunging into the Seine River from a platform near the Pont Alexandre III for the 1,500 metre swim.\n\nThe athletes weren't sure the race would take place until four hours before the start at 8 a.m. local time. Organizers had postponed the men's race on Tuesday and cancelled practice sessions on Monday and Sunday because the level of E.coli bacteria in the river was above the allowable limit.\n\nOvernight showers raised concerns that there might be another postponement or even cancellation of the swimming legs, turning the event into a duathlon of cycling and running. Persistent rainfall this spring and last weekend have overwhelmed treatment centers and allowed contaminated water to runoff into the river.\n\nAfter more testing and an analysis of weather forecasts, World Triathlon gave the go ahead early Wednesday for both the men's and women's events to take place that morning. \"We will swim\", the governing body declared on X.\n\nThe layout of the course offered spectacular views of the city and organizers had faced questions about whether they had put aesthetics above the safety of the athletes by sticking to their plan to use the Seine as a venue. But officials insisted that the health of competitors had always been paramount.\n\nBoth races began with athletes swimming two laps in the river near the bridge in the shadow of the Effiel Tower, where swift currents also posed challenge. The 40 kilometer cycling course involved seven circuits through the wet streets of central Paris including some slippery cobblestone sections that caused several crashes in the women's race. And the 10 kilometer run covered part of the same route for four laps.\n\nBermuda's Flora Duffy, who won gold in Tokyo, got out of the water first in the women's race followed by Bianca Seregni of Italy and Vittoria Lopes from Brazil. That trio was quickly overhauled in the cycling leg which was led by a pack of nine riders.\n\nThe lead group dwindled to four in the run; Julie Derron of Switzerland, Beth Potter of Britain and two French triathletes -- Cassandre Beaugrand and Emma Lombardi -- which sent fans lining the streets and bridges into a frenzy. Beaugrand pulled away in the final lap to win gold in 1:54:55, followed by Derron six seconds back and Potter who was nine seconds behind her. Canada's Emy Legault finished 35th.\n\nThe water quality of the Seine has been an issue for months and officials had been at pains to demonstrate that the river would be clean enough for the triathlon and the marathon swimming event next week. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a highly-publicized swim earlier this month and the city remains determined to open three sites along the river for public swimming next summer.\n\nFrench authorities have also invested \u20ac1.4-billion ($2.1-billion) on a variety of clean-up initiatives. One of the biggest is a new rainwater-retention basin that's capable of collecting 50,000 cubic metres of water, the equivalent of roughly 20 Olympic-sized swimming pools. The basin is supposed to handle runoff from summer storms.\n\nBut weeks of testing this spring have shown that levels of E. coli and enterococci, an intestinal bacteria, fluctuated wildly and soared as high as 10 times above the allowable limits some days this spring. Even on Tuesday, officials were saying the levels were still slightly above limits set by World Triathlon.\n\nAur\u00e9lie Merle, Paris 2024 executive director of sports, said Tuesday that testing showed results of between 980 colony-forming units/100 mL of water and 1,553 CFU/100 mL. The World Triathlon standard is 1,000 CFU/100 mL.\n\nThe men's triathlon is set to start later Wednesday morning and the mixed relay goes on Monday.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", The results of the latest water analyses have been deemed to be in order,\" said a statement made public in the early Wednesday hours.\n\nIt had been quite an ordeal for organisers, despite expressing optimism on Tuesday that the competition would take place as planned.\n\n\"There are unfortunate meteorological events outside of our control. We based our decision on the data and we are confident that the triathlon event could take place fully. Unfortunately, we are in XXI Century, where we can go from heavy rain to extreme heat in a few days, like we just saw, so I's hard to control the water quality of a river. We are sympathetic with the athletes and their families and have put contingency plans in place.\"\n\nThe president of World Triathlon, Spaniard Marisol Casado, also forecasted that the competition would be able to take place on Wednesday after days of sunshine hit the Paris streets and despite rain forecasts.\n\n\"We are disappointed but all in a good mood because we think that we are going to have an opportunity and we can find a different moment next week if we need to. Our athletes really want to compete. It's not unfair. It's part of the sport, just another situation of the competition.
